dialogues.text: ON A BLACK SCREEN: Credits. A RAUCOUS VOICE (SWIMMERВ’S) CHANTING IN THE CHEROKEE LAN A RANGE OF MOUNTAINS SLOWLY EMERGES: shrouded in a blue m like a Chinese water color. Below them, close to a small  town, YOUNG MEN, armed with vicious sticks and stripped t the waist, come charging in a muscular, steaming pack. Their opponents, also swinging sticks, attach the pack. A ball, barely round, made of leather, emerges, smacked  forwards by INMAN, who hurtles after it and collides with stick swung by SWIMMER, a young and lithe American Indian Inman falls, clutching his nose. The ball bobbles on the  ground in front of him. He grabs it and gets to his feet, the blood pouring from his nose. His team form a phalanx around him and he continues to ch A PRISTINE CABRIOLET pulled by an impressive horse, comes down towards the town. It has to pass across the temporar field of play, parting the teams. Some of the contestants grab their shirts to restore propriety as the Cabriolet a its two exotic passengers passes by. The driver is a man in his early fifties, dressed in the  severe garb of a minister, MONROE. And next to him, a sel conscious girl in the spotless elaborate, architectural s of the period, is his daughter, ADA. Inman, using his shi to staunch his battered nose, looks at Ada, astonished by her. An angel in this wild place. Now Swimmer stops chanting and begins, more hesitantly, t translate into English: SWIMMERВ’S VOICE (V.O.) You will be lonely. You will howl  like a dog as you walk alone. You  will carry dog shit cupped in your  hands. You will be smeared with dog  shit. Your spirit will wane and  dwindle to blue, the colour of  despair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Cabriolet passes, SWIMMER takes the ball an with a whoop starts to run towards the opposing goal. The game  resumes. Ada looks back as the men swarm into each other, sticks and fists flailing.

dialogues.text: A SIDE OF BEEF turns on a huge barbecue. The battered tea eating, drinking hard liquor, rehearsing victory and defe illuminated by a roaring bonfire. Swimmer is sewing up a  gash in InmanВ’s cheek as he continues to translate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is your path. There is no  other. That's a curse you can use on  the Yankee before battle.

dialogues.text: And that works?

The Monroes are introduced t various locals. Inamn watches them, on the other side of crowd. The Reverend Monroe, his daughter Ada. Up from  Charleston, bringing God's word to you heathens! Is Esco' preferred introduction. Building a church. Inman watches  Ada, moves his head to keep her in view as Swimmer stitch and winces with pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So keep your head still.

dialogues.text: (to Swimmer) Anyway, there won't be any war. And  if there is, they say it won't last  a week.

dialogues.text: THE OUTSKIRTS OF PETERSBURG. Massive wooden barricades in the shape of crosses, rows of X's, define the two lines. Federals have been laying siege for months. So early and  it's already hot. The trees are an oasis of green in a wo of mud between the two stark and ugly scars of the trench IN THE CONFEDERATE LINES, the men are rousing, boiling wa for coffee or to shave, smoking, stiff from night. There' large gun emplacement and some men still sleep against th stub-nosed cannon. Another RABBIT is disturbed from its h Ears pricked up to a distant rumbling. INT. TUNNEL. PREDAWN. A dark hole. Some evil place. A scraping sound. Shapes  burrowing forwards at a crouch. A silent purpose. EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. PREDAWN. Young OAKLEY, freshly recruited, approaches a group of me like him Highlanders from Company F of the 25th North Car Regiment. He doles out breakfast. Inman, loading his heav LeMats pistol, its nine rounds, is not hungry. Oakley ser another, ROURKE, last seen in the scrum at Cold Mountain. Oakley keeps his head low as he serves.

dialogues.text: Pandemonium. The Confederates are in complete disarray. T Federals pour forwards across NO MANS LAND, through the  peaceful oasis of trees, roaring the roar of attack. They flood towards the crater, hundreds of them, charging into dense and impenetrable WALL OF SMOKE.

Guns and m wheel round and empty into what is becoming a terrible de trap. Inman gets to his feet. Oakley with him, and rushes throu the smoke to the pit, emptying his LeMats into the crater LATER: A BLACK REGIMENT from the Union join the attack. An oozin layer cake of bodies, dead and frantically alive, drownin in slick. YOUNG OAKLEY loses his rifle and picks up a magazine case clubbing his opponent, then slips onto him and is stuck w a bayonet, the pain of which makes him squeal. INMAN GOES AT IT. He's grabbed from behi and crushed, a hand gouging at his face, an almighty stru He falls and lands on top of Oakley, and he and his Feder opponent fight to the death with the wounded boy as their pillow. dialogues.text: I'm reaching Cold Mountain before  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stobrod plays. It's wrenching. Oakley stills. Inman abrup puts his hand on the neck of the fiddle, stopping Stobrod The boy is dead. Inman gets to his feet and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONFEDERATE TENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A dozen men in the tent. Inman has a BOOK, its cover gone rolled up and tied with a leather strap. His bookmark is FADED TINTYPE PHOTOGRAPH of a solemn young woman. He unwr the book carefully and reads a page by the sickly light n to his bedroll. An OFFICER comes into the tent, approache Inman, who makes a stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get up, soldier. You are  mentioned tonight in my report. You  are a credit to the Highlands, to  North Carolina and to the Cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tight) Do you have news, sir, on my  application for transfer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. A bloody day. It's what our  General said: Good thing war is so  terrible else a man might end up  liking it too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. It was my understanding the  medical corps was desperate for  volunteers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, soldier, it's me who is  in need of volunteers. There's a  dozen Yankees in that stand of trees  between us. Stuck there from the  retreat. Come daylight they can shoot  us down for sport.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A beautiful night. Lots of stars. Inman and three others, including Butcher, slide over the top of the trench, far one side of the stand of trees. The plan is to cast a wid arc that will bring them around back of the trees, closer the enemy side than their own. The four men slither over ground. They pause. Inman has arrived at a tangle of corp He slithers over them. They work their way towards the trees. THERE ARE A HALF D FEDERALS CROUCHING IN THE COVER OF THE TREES. They are do Only one of them sits with a rifle surveying the Confeder lines, the others have their backs to the enemy, sitting  against the trunks, grabbing a few minute's sleep. As the four rebels approach, still crawling, one of the  Federals opens his eyes, sees the attack, shifts for his  rifle. INMAN IMMEDIATELY STANDS UP, FIRING INSTANTLY, kil him and two others, while Butcher throws himself at anoth The exchanges are brief and savage and one of Inman's par and all of the Federals lay dead. Then the rebels break f the trees. A FLARE goes up, then another, both from the Confederate  trenches. INMAN AND HIS ACCOMPLICES ARE PICKED OUT IN A  BRILLIANT GREEN LIGHT. Shots follow, from both sides, aim at the three returning men as they zigzag towards their o lines. As they get close, voices cry out, rippling down t trench, joining their own admonitions: Don't shoot, Hold  your fire, they're our boys, Hold your fire!!! They're al home. Butcher is laughing, whooping. Then just as suddenl he falls, wounded. Inman stops, turns back, runs to him. Inman collects Butcher, drags him, carries him. They're f yards from their lines. A BULLET CATCHES INMAN IN THE NEC He goes down like a tree, blood pouring from his neck. Ly on the ground, he watches the phosphorescent lights slowl fade to black, all sound fading with them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. 3 YEARS EARLIER. DAY
dialogues.text: A WOODEN JOIST swings across the view of the Blue Ridge. are swarming over the roof of an unfinished CHAPEL, below which appears the small town of COLD MOUNTAIN. Among the  workers, armed with nails and hammer, knees clutching a  rafter, is Inman, fresh and a whole lifetime younger. Rou and Butcher are also there hammering, building, kidding a and Oakley, barely a teenager. Below them, women are setting up a lunch for the workers, ADA amongst them. She has the circumspect air of the blue stocking, uncomfortably aware of the dirt beneath her hem the men's radar for her every move. Inman watches her as  Sally Swanger approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ada, as Monroe  moves off) Ada, how are you settling in? Are  you liking the farm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much. It's beautiful country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So listen -- if you would say hello  to one of these fools, I'll get a  field cleared this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone? Like a forfeit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at Inman  who immediately looks  away) No. Him in particular, up in the  rafters. Been pressing me all morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP ON THE ROOFBEAMS OF THE CHAPEL, the men are preoccupie with talk of secession from the Union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hammering) I call this nail: Northern Aggression. (hammering) I call this nail: a free nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show some respect -- these nails are  making a church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hammering) I call this nail: respect the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada comes over, carrying a tray of lemonade glasses. Call up to Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman swings down. He feels the other men staring, burnin hole in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ada Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W. P. Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W. P. Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repeating a thing doesn't improve  it. (shrugs) People call me Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to take a glass of  lemonade your friends might stop  staring. Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops down to ground level, takes the lemonade, scowls the other guys. They're breaking for lunch and as they ma their way to the trestle tables -- they enjoy jostling In

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work wood. Got a piece of land.  Mostly work wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear fields?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) I can clear a field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, was there something in particular  you wished to say to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks about it) Not that comes to me. (hands back the glass) I'll say thank you for the lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he turns and joins the other men gathering round the  tables for lunch. Ada watches him, intrigued. Rourke and approach ESCO SWANGER, a known sympathizer with the North to give him a bad time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esco loves the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer a Yankee to a halfwit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman arrives just as Rourke points a warning finger at E He pushes the finger down to get by. Esco continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you think you'd be fighting  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that when it's at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esco's sons, ELLIS AND ACTON, who're working at the other end of the building, have now arrived at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, you causing trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cut the wood, you carry the water  for good old King Cotton. Now you  want to fight for him. Somebody has  to explain it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rourke and the  others) Don't even try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others are desperate to tease Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the lemonade? Sweet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada, at the lemonade stand again, watches them laughing a Inman, who keeps his head fixed on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONFEDERATE LINES. NIGHT
dialogues.text: INMAN, ON A GURNEY, carried, someone with a cloth to his  neck, which is soaked through with blood. They start to r with him, heading for the field hospital, worried that he will die before the wound can be staunched, cauterized. Throughout, A STRANGE MUSIC PLAYS, discordant notes jangl

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: -- from A PIANO, lashed to a cart, as it bounces along th lane, passing the Swanger Farm. Sally comes out to look.  It's Ada riding next to one of the farmhands, a second bo keeping watch over the piano. Sally goes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fine looking thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been missing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, by the way. (from Ada's quizzical  look) Inman's down in the bottom field,  clearing his debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear. And then he had nothing to  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are men so different in Charleston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men? I don't know. I don't even know  what a woman should be like. In  Charleston I was called a thistle,  twice, by two different men. Both of  them -- they were hunting for a  simile, what was I like -- and thistle  came right to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're saying you might like him,  why not go down and say hello.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman's working in the field, stripped to his undershirt, hot work, wielding a scythe. He hears something and looks at the edge of the lane, ADA IS PLAYING THE PIANO, which still strapped to the cart. She briefly raises a hand to  Inman, then nods to the farmhand who sets them on their w again. Inman smiles, waves back, watching as the cart rum off down the track.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It's pouting with rain. INSIDE THE FARMHOUSE, ADA IS PLAY THE PIANO. Men and women crowd into the parlour, in best clothes,  celebrating the completion of the Chapel. Inman is outsid on the porch, his coat soaked, water pouring off his hat. looks at Ada. She finishes. Monroe steps in front of the  applause, smiling. His words of thanks leak through the w to Inman, who stands, watching, listening.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PARLOUR, BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Monroe circulates, with Ada. He nods at a group of men, w congregate in one part, not mingling. Their leader, TEAGU might be a minister himself, favouring a black dress coat black crow in the corner, eyes flashing. Ada doesn't know them. Esco comes by. Monroe puts a hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esco, our friends there -- (indicating Teague  and co.) -- they helped build the Chapel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Teague and his boys. I'd  recommend you kick them out except a  man don't kick a snake. One time the  Teague family owned the whole of  Cold Mountain. My farm, your farm,  all belonged to his grand-daddy.  Teague wanted this place bad. You  got it. He's here sniffing out an  advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no advantage here, but to  celebrate a job well done. Cheers -- (he raises his glass) -- and thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Teague raises his glass across the room.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada appears at the door opening it onto the porch. She's  carrying a tray with drinks. Acknowledges Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you planning to come inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wetter than a fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a good fire going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody said you were enlisting. (no response) Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's a war we'll all fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) If there's a mountain we'll all climb,  if there's an ocean we'll all drown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call a thing a war makes it a  challenge to some men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a picture made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tintype, with your gun and your  courage on display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're laughing at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always carrying a tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking a drink over to the negroes  in the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the tray) I'll do that. I can't get much wetter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into the night rain. She watches him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: A beautiful day, the farm peaceful. Inman walks up the pa to the farmhouse, its borders flowering and pretty, a sla woman weeding. He knocks on the door. Monroe answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman hovers, awkward. Ada appears, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some sheet music. Belonged to  my father. No use to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada comes forward, takes the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should probably get along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Inman is more comfortable  outdoors. Perhaps we might take a  walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A splendid idea.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Monroe and Inman and Ada touring the farm. It's a biggish property, over three hundred acres. And well-tended by th dozen slave farmhands who work it, some of whom are dotte about in the landscape. Rolling mountains dominate the vi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expansive) I want to get sheep into this field.  A big field doesn't look right without  sheep. You're a lucky fellow, Mr.  Inman, you've had this view all your  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a special view. I dragged my  poor daughter to Cold Mountain from  Charleston because of my Doctors --  they say my heart is weak -- so the  air's meant to do me good. But it's  the view I think heals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada walking behind, comes alongside the two men, threadin her arm into her father's but, by so doing, also arriving next to Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get on my visits. Can I  offer you a ride back into town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman looks at Ada. No word.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PARLOUR, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: From the window Ada watches the Cabriolet head towards to At the piano, she unwraps the leather lace from the packa of music. Inside the first book of music, there's a  DAGUERREOTYPE OF INMAN with his LeMats, a typical Confede pose. Some of the music has left its imprint on the pictu the notes like a melody over Inman's face. Ada picks them out on the piano. The ebullient sound of Shape Singing. A noisy choir letti rip --

dialogues.speaker: -- THE WHOLE CHURCH IS SINGING, MEN TO ONE SIDE
dialogues.text: THE OTHER. Monroe conducts, sings. Inman is there, as is  Ada. He fixes on her neck, the way the hair falls. The door bursts open. Young OAKLEY, apologetic nod to Mon sits at the back, then leans forward, as the singing  continues, to say something to Rourke, who says something Butcher, the news spreading like wildfire. Rourke gets up leaves. Butcher gets up next, follows. Another man. Anoth Depleting the male voices, until only women and some of t older men are singing and one side of the church is  practically empty. Inman, remains, fixed on Ada. Who does not look round.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Those left in the congregation now spill out into what ha become a melee as the NEWS OF SECESSION goes up. Enormous excitement, particularly among the boys, who now seem  curiously attractive to the girls. Inman blinks out into sun, Ada finds him. They're awkward as they watch other  sweethearts embracing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you have your war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEAGUE AND HIS MEN COME RIDING UP THE STREET, their horse clearing a path amongst the celebrating crowd. Teague rei in his horse and rides it up against Esco Swanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those who follow Lincoln, or preach  abolition, best keep one eye open  when they're sleeping, Old Bogey Man  might get you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman steps between Esco and Teague, holding the reins of Teague's horse, easy and dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the law all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teague produces a document, which he waves in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, son. Home Guard for  Haywood County. I'm the law from  today. You all go fight now. We'll  watch your sweethearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he spurs on his horse, his fellow Home Guard falling behind, riding on over the ridge. Inman walks to Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might be safer back in Charleston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then who'll be waiting for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts a hand on his arm for a second. They both want t get to the point of declaration but don't know how. They  stand, people noisy around them, those about to leave, th about to be left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to walk back inside the  Chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he does so, making his meaning clear for her to follo

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman walks inside. Stands with his back to the door. It  opens and closes. Inman turns. It's Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you want a quiet word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the door opens again and it's Ada. She's dismayed to her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates they should both leave. Inman sits at a benc

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Monroe and Ada come into town in their cabriolet. They pa under banners proclaiming the Confederate cause: Old Rip' Awake! Watch out Yankees! The trap draws up by the Cold  Mountain General Store. Monroe lets Ada down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of his appointment) I'll daresay Dr. O'Brien'll want to  do a test or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there'll be a coffee or  two, a brandy or two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monroe smiles in acknowledgement, gets back in the trap. heads into the store.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. ROOMING HOUSE. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: INMAN SITS ON HIS BED, wearing pants and a vest. His room like a monk's cell. Nothing in it. Inman's trunk is packe He's polishing his boots, in his bare feet. One hand insi the boot, the other blacking it. There's a knock at the d He opens it. It's Ada. He abruptly closes the door on her

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, ROOMING HOUSE. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada waits outside. She's not sure what's happening. Then  Inman opens the door. He's buttoning his shirt. His boots are on, one conspicuously dirty, one highly polished. Som walks up the stairs, carrying a jug and bowl. They separa as the man passes them. They're tender, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found you this book. William  Bartram. They tell me it's good. I  think he writes about these parts,  the author, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman takes it. She has something else. Wrapped in paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this... (hands it to him) I'm not smiling in it. I don't know  how to do that, hold a smile, so now  I'm solemn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE KISSES HER, pressing into her, his arm circling her wa Below them the sound of a MARCHING BAND. It's the RECRUIT PARADE and brings Rourke and Butcher racing down the stai Inman pulls away from Ada as the boys hurtle for the fron door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Rourke, Butcher, and then Inman appear in the doorway of Rooming House, and then fall in with the motley crew of  Volunteers AS THEY MARCH BY WITH THE BAND AND THE ENLISTE SOLDIERS. The town is out to wish them well, parents, you brothers, sweethearts walking alongside their brave men. comes to the door of the Rooming House. Inman looks back sees her, but almost immediately loses her in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RAILROAD.
dialogues.text: A TRAIN with the seriously injured snakes past the back o the Confederate lines -- its suburbs of supplies, arrivin and departing troops -- and into peaceful country. FIDDLE PLAYS, THEN A BANJO.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOX CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: A CROWDED WAGON. It's a cauldron, and those able smash th the wooden walls to make a breathing hole. Some have thei heads thrust out like crated poultry. INMAN IS IN THERE,  neck bandaged, its ugly seepage making a bloody necklace. The light plays black and white through the boarded sides the boxcar, flashing on Inman's face as he drifts in and of consciousness. He focuses and sees the strange head of STOBROD'S FIDDLE. Stobrod is serenading him, accompanied an angel-faced and extremely heavy child-man, PANGLE, who grin of delight seems permanent even in this claustrophob grim world. Inman is panicked, puts a hand to push the fi away. His voice is a croak, spoiled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pangle) What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says he ain't about to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Inman) Truth to tell they say you are,  Soldier. We'll meet again, in the  better world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He changes his tune, and the tempo, finding a foot-slappi rhythm, the two musicians grinning at each other. Inman l back into unconsciousness. The rhythm becomes a hammering sound...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: -- AS A MAN HAMMERS A TINTYPE OF HIS SON'S FACE into the  wooden porch of the Chapel, where it joins many other  portraits of those lost to the war. Monroe presides. One the slaves from Black Cove holds the ladder for the berea father. Other families wait, with their own daguerreotype mount. It's a memorial service without bodies. Riders approach. Home Guard. Teague brings his horse up  alongside Monroe at the Chapel door, tips his hat in  condolence to the bereaved families. With him is a young, intensely beautiful and flamboyant rider, BOSIE, his hair long, a single fingernail bizarrely overgrown. Somehow  sinister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My condolences to you all. (he considers the  slave) Keep an eye on the negro. They want  what the white man got -- all of you  watch out your brave boys give their  lives to war and meantime your slaves  carry murder, rape and arson to your  firesides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only slaves within twenty miles  labor on my farm. They're good  Christians and I'll vouchsafe for  them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APPROACH TO BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Cold Mountain at its loveliest. The CABRIOLET with Monroe and his daughter heads towards the farm. At a bend they m a couple of riders, TWINS, from Teague's Home Guard, ridi furiously past them. Monroe reins in the trap and lets th thunder past before continuing on their way home. Monroe intrigued by Ada, as if he's never looked at her before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking -- at this moment, I  don't know why -- you're looking  exactly like your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you see the doctor you  get melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens to my heart and I get  emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives you alcohol and you get  emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She squeezes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We commiserate about the folly of  this terrible war. (they ride in silence) Do you worry when there's no word  from him? (no response) From Mr. Inman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But then I've tried counting  the number of words which passed  between Mr. Inman and me. (looking ahead, seeing  smoke) Is that a bonfire? So close to the  barns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they see THE FAMILY OF SLAVES turn off the road as t cabriolet approaches, running away into the fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting at the  disappearing slaves) Hey! Stop there! Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monroe gets out of the cabriolet and runs into the fields after the retreating family, who are carrying bundles, ch personal items, all loaded up. Ada has already taken the  reins and has driven up to the house. THE BARN IN WHICH T SLAVE FAMILY HAD LIVED IS ON FIRE. Monroe catches one of women, remonstrates with her. She's upset, distressed, on of her sons comes back, pushes Monroe to the ground. They hurry away. Monroe gets up, hurries to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: A FIGURE SWINGS IN THE HEAT OF THE FLAMES, HANGING FROM A
dialogues.text: BEAM. Monroe spies it as he catches up with Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Daddy, it's not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure swings round. IT'S AN EFFIGY, A GROTESQUE  CARICATURE OF A BLACK MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) What is wrong with us all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada turns and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get help. (shouting over her  shoulder) Keep away from the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monroe stands and considers the flames. Ada turns back on more to see him -- a small man silhouetted against the bl

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAY
dialogues.text: INMAN lies; bandaged, eyes closed, in THE BALLROOM OF A  COLONIAL MANSION, co-opted as one ward of a Confederate  hospital. Rows of beds, the wounded and the dying, are lo between some vestiges of the room's former glory. SOME LOCAL WOMEN, conscious of their duty to the cause, a brought through by an exhausted doctor, who's lost all hi grace. The windows are open, but it's still insufferably  hot, the muslin curtains barely moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of these men will be dead by  the morning or, if they're stubborn,  by nightfall. I have other men outside  in the quadrangle waiting for the  beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women try to process this, the attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, any kind word will be a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One woman is overpowered by the stench, gags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the heat. I'm sorry. They rot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women begin to approach the beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pray. If they're not God fearing  you can stir up a hornet's nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. MORGAN, nervous, decent, sits next to INMAN. His mou is moving. She doesn't know what he's saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, you want water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bends to him again. His voice is a faint croak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pigeon River. Little East Fork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor is on his exit, stops at the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't know what he's  saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ramble. Names of loved ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening to Inman) Pigeon River. Is that a place? Cold  Mountain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor shrugs, not a detective, moves on, stops at th man in the next bed. Has a brief look, calls to a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is dead.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Monroe and Ada are outside, a picnic at the summer table, autumn leaves blowing up around them. Nearby the charred  skeleton of the barn. Ada gets up, clears away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (staying her for grace) For your Providence, Oh lord, we  thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen. That was the last of the ham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to learn how to cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to say something in  Chapel. Perhaps some of the womenfolk  will volunteer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't have people coming here and  cooking for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault. I should have raised  you less like a companion and more  like a young woman. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sorry, but I don't know how  we'll get through another winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you play me something? Something  peaceful while I look over my sermon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada takes the dishes away. He gets out his papers, his pe and ink.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PARLOUR, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: ADA PLAYS THE PIANO. Chopin's Prelude in E Minor. Outside the garden, Monroe has adjourned to his striped campaign  chair, and is hunched over his notes. The door of the par is open and the music floats over to him as he works. Ada plays. A FEW SPOTS OF RAIN appear at the window. Then the steady drumming of a summer shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still playing) Daddy, bring the tablecloth in with  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plays some more. Monroe hasn't come in. The rain spla on to the window..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, come inside before you drown!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a few more bars, she stops playing and, curious, go to the door. She stands at the doorway. MONROE'S SERMON I

dialogues.speaker: CAUGHT IN THE WIND AND BLOWS AROUND HIM, THE INK RUN TO
dialogues.text: ABSTRACTIONS, his hand dropped and visible to Ada as, wit dread, she approaches. SHE CATCHES THE SODDEN PAPERS, CHA AFTER THEM, THEN REACHES HER DEAD FATHER. He's like a fish, his face shining with the rain, and gla eyed. She leans in to him, her head to his heart, then ru oblivious to the rain, her dress already drenched, runs d the lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Mr. Inman...

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. NIGHT
dialogues.text: INMAN'S FACE as he drifts in and out of consciousness. Mr Morgan, the hospital volunteer, sits by Inman's bed. She  holds ADA'S UNOPENED LETTER, badly weather damaged, the p stuck together, the writing blurred where the ink has run

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's come to you by way of Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are various dates, which she decodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not too recent -- written this  past winter. I'm afraid I can't read  who it's from. Dear Mr. Inman,

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada is writing at her father's desk. A lonely room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm still waiting, as I promised  I would, but I find myself alone and  at the end of my wits --

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Morgan reads to Inman, trying to decipher the letter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- at the end of my wits, so now I  say to you, plain as I can, come  back to me. Come back to me is my  request. (can't read the next  bit) Then something I can't read,  something, come back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is very still. Then, eyes glinting with determinati gives a TINY NOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By order of Zebulon Vance, Governor  of this great state of North Carolina:  any soldier turned deserter is guilty  of treason and shall be hunted down  like a dog.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada walks down the hill from the Chapel. There is an abse of young people, but the older folk are gathered round th General Store where a UNIFORMED OFFICIAL is reading from document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Any man takes in a deserter is  likewise guilty of treason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Official is flanked by Teague, Bosey and the twins, p up with self-importance. Ada has to walk around him to en the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Home Guard is powered to enter  any place it sees fit, without notice  or constraint. Names of all deserters  will be posted in every town,  published in every newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GENERAL STORE, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: The Official continues outside as Ada enters. Ada approac Mrs Castlereagh, the owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a letter for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing -- we're getting no post  through at all -- although if you  slip out back the material you ordered  has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to the back of the store, to a screened-off area. Mrs. Castlereagh hands her over a packet of material. The another, more furtive, transaction to take place. Mrs  Castlereagh hands over a second parcel as if it were  narcotics. Ada tears at the wrapping. It's a parcel of bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If folks knew I was taking deliveries  from the North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sooner we lose this war the  better. Already one boy gone, another  with his leg took off at the knee.  That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is they say not one boy  in ten from these mountains is coming  home again and most of them are  deserters.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GENERAL STORE, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada emerges, almost collides with Teague. She wriggles pa him, tries to make her package invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT'S WINTER. A solitary RIDER jogs his horse through the  frost, towards Black Cove farm. Ada is working at a handpump, failing to coax water from well. She's wrapped in blankets. The farm is somewhat unk and so is she. The hem of her skirt is frayed. She rips a it tearing off a strip of material, which she binds aroun the handle in an attempt to thaw the mechanism. Then she  looks up to see the horseman approaching. It's Teague. Ad immediately heads inside the house. Teague arrives at the house, takes a brace of RABBITS fro his saddlebag. He heads for the gate. The gate needs oili the path is overgrown, he looks at the pump handle, the  abandoned pitcher. Ada opens the door, pinning her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's taken me too long, but I've  come to pay my respects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands over the rabbits) I reckoned you might need fattening  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada takes them. She is very queasy with these dead animal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This house must bring bad luck. Killed  my granddaddy to lose it, then my  daddy died on account of not having  it, then your daddy died on account  of getting it. We should burn it  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't somebody try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot to manage without help. Need a  hand with that pump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy to volunteer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not to volunteer for the war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war? I wanted to go. But you  know: too old, too literate. Plus I  got no spleen. Lost it from a horse's  kick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got no spleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the thing about an organ. You  don't know you need it till you lost  it. (suddenly busy with a  bayonet) I want to clear this path. I can  just as soon do it and talk as stand  around and talk. Then you can say  men beat a path to your door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd really prefer it if you didn't  do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rather I did my job? (scything at the path) See if there's any material I should  confiscate. For the war effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was raised in the good manners of  the South where a gentleman doesn't  enter a house with a woman alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now he's at the pump) Good manners didn't quite make it to  these mountains. If it don't yield  meat, or you can't sit on it, or  suck on it... (he gets the pump  going, water pours  out) And you're sleeping all right? These  cold dark nights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sleeping fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be a long hard winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and stops at the gate, runs his hands through hi hair and uses the grease to ease the hinge. Then steps up onto his horse, and rides away. Ada watches him. Shudders

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada comes into the kitchen. A weak oil-lamp reveals THE T RABBITS, partially covered on a plate, flies buzzing arou them, a little liquid leaking from them. Ada takes a knif and contemplates skinning gutting them. Suddenly she gath them up and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: ADA BURIES THE TWO RABBITS. The wind howls. She covers th little hole with soil and stones. Pumps out water to wash her hands. Thinks she hears a noise, listens, alert to an unfamiliar sounds, then hurries back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada comes inside, she closes the door. Locks it. Puts a c against it. Goes upstairs, to her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada enters her bedroom. It's a chaos of books, clothes,  dishes. She closes the door, sets another chair against i Then drags her armchair up against that, books and papers spilling onto the floor. She props up Inman's portrait, o the chair, as if he were guarding her. Sits on the bed an desolate, begins to write:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I imagine you are dead and,  that it is to your spirit I am  writing? No word from you in all  this time. If you receive this please  know I am here and warring, too,  with a faint heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THERAPY FOR WOUNDED SOLDIERS. Some of those convalescing  swim or are helped to paddle in the healing sea. There ar rudimentary wheelchairs. Inman, a long way from home, is  amongst those sitting in one of these, very still, grey a sick -- but alive. He pulls at the dressing on his neck,  exposing the still raw and livid wound to the sea air. Inman has his Bartram, his bookmark is the battered and f picture of Ada, which he considers, before continuing to  read. Behind him A HUNDRED SLAVES AT WORK IN THE FIELDS, and be them the Mansion which has become the hospital. A series bells, of shouts, and the slaves stop working, prepare fo the long walk home, congregating, then forming a line, he by the foremen. Inman eases his position to bend over and dip his bandage the seawater. He brings the wet bandage to his neck, cons the ocean, his fellow ragtag of wounded, the slaves, the  great fields, the Mansion. The whole meaning of this war  around him. A GRAVEL VOICE STARTS TO SING THE BLUES, CONT

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DUSK
dialogues.text: The men return to the Hospital. A BLIND MAN IS SELLING PE which he roasts over a small fire. HE'S SINGING AS --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHAPEL, COLD MOUNTAIN TOWN. DAY
dialogues.text: -- A tintype of OAKLEY is added to the Chapel's votives,  hammered in alongside Rourke and Butcher. There are fifty more images now, the paint flaking around them. The exter of the Chapel, three years on, has taken on the burden of recording history. There is no minister, no services, just the votives,  daguerreotypes or simply the names of those missing in ac accompanied by tiny vases of wildflowers. The town shroud in mist, and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. SPRING. DAY
dialogues.text: EVERYWHERE SIGNS OF PROFOUND NEGLECT, like a Grimm's fair tale of a deserted house. The fields are overgrown with w the gardens abandoned. The chickens have deserted the hen and are wandering around the outbuildings, scuffing at th packed dirt. Sally and Esco come up the overgrown path, avoiding the  chickens, and knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada! Ada, It's Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're seen from ground level, through a boxwood, as the feet patrol the ground, turn away from the door, and then retreat, their voices drifting away. Ada is there, crouch in her hidey-hole, a blanket on the ground, her book. She wants to reveal herself, but is too embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you look at the state of this  place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor soul. She's got nobody and  nothing and three hundred acres of  misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this a ROOSTER, black and gold, struts into the  boxwood. As the rooster approaches, Ada shudders, tries t shoo it away without alerting her presence. Ada peers thr the boxwood as Sally and Esco close the gate and recede. rooster comes at her again. She rises up, kicking out at while he flares his wings, spurs flaying at her. Ada runs from the boxwood, tormented by the triumphant rooster, wh continues to fly and scratch, driving her into the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada dabs at the scratches, her dress rolled down to the w to reveal her arms and shoulders. Now she shucks off the  dress completely and tries to find a clean replacement. T isn't one, so she hunts through the overflowing laundry b for something less dirty.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MONROE'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada enters her father's room, wearing undergarments. Everything as he left it and, in contrast to the rest of house, extremely tidy. She opens a wardrobe, finds one of his coats, puts it on. It's much too big, and she rolls u the sleeves, catches her pinched face and disheveled face a swivel mirror. She turns the mirror away and the image  swings into --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GATES OF HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAY
dialogues.text: -- the figure of Inman walking, frail, grey. A kind of  lurching walk, as if his balance isn't guaranteed. He get close to the gate and interests a Guard, on the lookout f would-be deserters. A BLIND MAN IS SELLING PEANUTS which roasts over a small fire. He's always singing. Inman  approaches. When Inman speaks, his voice is a croak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting better all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't hurry. War's almost done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you take your wound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I was born. Never saw a thing  in this world, not a tree a gun or a  woman. Though I put my hand on all  three. Couple of things I felt back  there I'd sure liked to have had a  long look at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's shoveling some peanuts into a twist of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you give for that? To  have your eyeballs back for ten  minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes! Wouldn't give an Indian  head cent. I fear it might turn me  hateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sure what seeing's done to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't the way I meant it. You  said ten minutes. It's having a thing  and then the loss I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we don't agree. There's not  much I wouldn't give for ten minutes  of someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someplace or someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch yourself. They're shooting  men who take themselves a walk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREE PROMENADE, CHARLESTON. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman and a bunch of other walking wounded make their way under supervision, towards the town. The grandeur of the  approach, the carriages. The sorry state of the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTHOUSE, CHARLESTON. DAY
dialogues.text: TWO GREAT TRESTLE TABLES, LOADED WITH CLOTHES. Underneath the tables, boots -- laced together, origins various. The charitable womenfolk are helping match clothes to recover soldiers, some of whom are still on crutches, or in  wheelchairs. Inman finds a black dresscoat, some pants, a pair of boots. He accumulates a little pile. On his way o AN ELDERLY AND STAUNCH CONFEDERATE GENTLEMAN shakes his h and gives him an apple from the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TEMPORARY BARBERSHOP, CHARLESTON. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman emerges from the Courthouse and joins the line for shave at the makeshift barbershop set up outside the  Courthouse. Two barbers, two chairs. A VERY ELEGANT SQUAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman settles in the seat. The Barber contemplates his sc beard, the livid, scabbed wound on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) I'll cut your hair, but I ain't about  to shave you. That thing opens up,  your head's liable to falloff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is almost dawn. The window by Inman's bed is a frame g onto the still dark world. The Night Guard passes by on i patrol of the perimeter. A CLEAN-SHAVEN INMAN IS FULLY DR UNDER THE COVERS. He gets his hat, pushes his book into h knapsack and, with one step up, WALKS OUT OF THE WINDOW A INTO THE WORLD.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE OCEAN BY THE HOSPITAL, CHARLESTON. DAWN
dialogues.text: Inman, his footprints in the sand, as he hurries along by the edge of the ocean, away from the hospital...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: -- as Ada walks, the wind kicking up around her, past the Swanger place. She's bent and curiously dressed in her  father's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Swanger calls out from the field. She's concerned a Ada's gaunt, ragged appearance. Ada waits for her approac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're skinny as a whippet, girl --  you're coming indoors with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm not -- I need to clean  some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great God, you ever looked at my  husband! I can't get him to wear  decent Church clothes Christmas  morning. Hang on to me, the wind'll  blow you over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she folds her arm into Ada's. They walk up the lane.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SWANGER FARM. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Ada eats. Esco across from her contemplating her evident  appetite, the oversized man's jacket. Sally ladles more f onto Ada's plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go back to that dark house.  There's a bed here, least till our  boys get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your daddy's coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was saying to Sally, I wasn't  expecting to be visiting, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't suit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to chuckle, then Ada, too, then Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get up to your place this  week. (of Sally) She's mad at me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't expect -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- more than I can do to keep this  place half-managed. I'm ready-to  stop, I tell you. I just want to sit  on my porch with Sal, watch my boys  in the field, holler good job! every  hour or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your people in Charleston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no people. And no money.  My father had some bonds and  investments. They're worthless now,  of course, the war has... they're  not worth anything. (they look at each  other) I love it here. In spite of  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And waiting on a feller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look from Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down our well. (Sally's disgusted  with him) She should! Look down our well with  a mirror, you'll see the future.  S'what they say. (to Sally) You do it! Don't make that face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it ain't rightly Christian,  but it's what folks do, like when  they dangle a needle over the belly  to see if you're carrying a boy or a  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of mirror?

dialogues.speaker: CROWS.
dialogues.text: Ada is bent backwards over the well, a hand mirror glinti down into the blackness. The reflection is elusive agains the bright evening sky, the sun almost set, and low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried many a time, never saw a  dickybird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The image is clearer. The trees sharpen, the figure walki the steep incline of the corridor, all fiercely black and white as if it were a carpet of snow and black hieroglyph of trees, and crows flying. The trick of the glass and th watery disc of the well surface. A buzzing in Ada's ears, something like a distant music. Then the figure seems to  suddenly pitch forwards, but at that moment, Ada -- cante over, getting dizzy has to move and the image flies away, replaced with the sky, the flash of the setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada's faint. She sits up, blank, a little shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday I found myself crouched  over a well like a mad woman, which  I suppose I have become

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLANTATION. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman walks along an expanse of marshland. Great cranes f heavily over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and staring down into its secrets,  I thought I saw you there, walking  back to me --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Ada is writing in her father's campaign chair, a blanket  wrapped around her, a rake propped next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- or wished I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That cow wants milking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada looks up from her writing with a start. She covers he letter, guiltily, instinctively. In front of her, at the  gate, is A YOUNG RAWBONED, FERAL WOMAN, OF INDETERMINATE  ORIGINS. She is barefoot, and dressed in a hand-dye_ shif of blue. Her name is RUBY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that letter ain't urgent, the cow  is -- is what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Lady Swanger says you need some  help. Here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada is instantly defensive, intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need help, I need, I do need help,  but I need a laborer -- there's  plowing and rough work and -- I think  there's been a misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the rake for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't for gardening, that's for sure.  Number one -- you got a horse I can  plow all day. I'm a worker. Number  two there's no man better than me  cause there's no man around who ain't  old or full of mischief. I know your  plight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My plight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I hard to hear cause you keep  repeating everything. I'm not looking  for money, never cared for it and  now it ain't worth nothing. I expect  to board and eat at the same table.  I'm not a servant. Do you get my  meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People'll have to empty their own  night jars, that's my point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm not planning to work while  you watch neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a yes or a no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at Ruby) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's half the day yet. Let's make  a start. My name's Ruby. I know your  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rake: there's a rooster devil,  I'm sure of it. He's Lucifer himself.  I go near him he's at me with his  spurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I despise a flogging rooster. Where  is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada gets up, nods to the corner of the yard. Ruby goes ov The Rooster gathers himself up for a new opponent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's put him in a pot.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CORNFIELDS. DAWN
dialogues.text: Inman's walking on a track which passes through cornfield the crop high and thick around him. He stops, hearing  something. Riders. He wades into the field, seeking cover the tall crop, lying in the dirt. Horses appear. HOME GUA

dialogues.speaker: MEN ON PATROL, A CHAIN GANG OF PRISONERS
dialogues.text: IN TOW, A COUPLE OF FEDERAL SOLDIERS. They have dogs, whi sniff and growl, intrigued by the fields, called back by Home Guard. Inman waits until they're well out of sight. AS HE GETS T

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER, THEN ANOTHER, THEN ANOTHER, ALL SLAVES ON THE RU
dialogues.text: DOTTED AROUND THE FIELD. He walks to the road, paying no  heed to them. They assemble, paying no heed to him and mo off in the opposite direction. Inman turns, looks at them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! (they stop, turn) I'd pay a dollar for an egg. A piece  of cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him, then continue on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada wakes up to persistent knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada? Ada? You up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (opening her eyes) It's still dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the cows that. It's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada enters blearily, clutching her novel. Ruby already bu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to eat something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have to get up earlier. (at Ada's book) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heading outside) You want to carry a book carry one  you can write in --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAWN
dialogues.text: Ruby emerges, followed by Ada, chewing on a tomato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we got our own story. Called Black  Cove Farm: a catastrophe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back at Ada for a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can spell it, too. C-a-t-a-s-t-r-o- phe. Learned the same place you did,  in the schoolroom. That's one of the  first words they taught me. Ruby  Thewes, you are a ca-t-a-s-t-r-o-p-h- e...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're heading for the stable.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STABLE, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby's already pitching hay. Turns to Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mucking out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada half-asleep, obedient, stunned by this energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years I was in school before  my daddy -- saying God rest his soul  is like wishing him what he had in  life, cause he lived to rest, he was  born tired -- before my daddy decided  there was better use for my backside  than have it sat all day in front of  a blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A FIELD OF WEEDS, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby dictates a list to Ada as they bustle along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number One -- layout a winter garden  for cool season crops: turnips,  onions, cabbage, greens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada scribbles, walks, scribbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby up a ladder, inspecting the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number Two: patch the shingles on  the barn roof. Do we have a maul and  froe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing, holding the  ladder) Maul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-a-u-l.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COLD HOUSE, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby cleans out leaves and detritus from the stone channe allowing the stream to flow free and cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number three: clay crocks for  preserves. Tomatoes. Beans. Jams.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: Ruby doing her version of soil analysis, scrunching the e tasting it, spitting it out. Ada makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear and turn this field. No harm  done letting it go fallow, now we'll  do well.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OUTBUILDINGS, BLACK COVE FARM. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Ruby looks up. Ada catches up with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number fifteen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number sixteen: let's get a martin  colony going in the Gourd House.  Keep away crows. You got one thing  in abundance on this farm and that's  crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a Gourd House?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APPLE ORCHARD, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: Ruby, delighted, contemplates the bounty of apples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's survival. On them trees. (turns to an exhausted  Ada) You got a cider press or would that  be wishing on a blessing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, yes, I think we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby whoops, jogs away. Ada, exhausted takes a bite of an apple, watches her.

dialogues.speaker: INMAN WALKS A ROCKY TRACK, FALLING AWAY TO THE RIVER AT O
dialogues.text: SIDE, A STEEP CLIFF TO THE OTHER, the way itself broken a precarious, bad country to meet an enemy. Inman sees A LIGHT in the distance, a torch flicking in a out of view, like a star to follow. He stops, narrows his eyes to focus on the view, listening hard. He pulls out t Lemats.

dialogues.speaker: GORGE.
dialogues.text: The horse has a burden -- a sack or wrapped bundle draped over either side of the saddle. The attempts to heave the bundle onto his shoulders. He can't, and the bundle slips the ground, cover falling enough to glimpse an arm, a hea IT IS THE BODY OF A BLACK GIRL. The man tries again to li her. He's clearly upset, despairing, his hat comes off to reveal long, dandy's hair, all extravagant curls. He stag with the weight of the girl, heading for the lip of the d gorge. He kisses the girl again and again, cheeks, mouth, mumbli to her. He's at the edge now and can just let her go. THE INMAN'S GUN IS AT HIS TEMPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let go. Just back up, nice and  steady, do this all in reverse, you're  going to end up with her draped back  over your animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pull that trigger. I am a man  of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've killed several of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I am God's minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What part of God's business is  throwing a woman down a gorge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slave woman, can you see that in  this light? She's black as a bucket  of tar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's retreating, on his way back to the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugged her. Like you would a  butterfly. And I care for her, that's  the heartbreak of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has the girl back on the horse. Inman brings the torch to his face. It's tear-stained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got my bastard in her belly.  What kind of pistol is that I never  saw the like of it?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VEASEY TOWN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Inman leads the horse, with Veasey ahead of him, hands ti behind his back, desperate for a reprieve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm begging you. It's better you  blowout my brains than return me to  this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does she live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In our house. She sleeps in our  kitchen. You don't know me, friend,  but the good Lord punished me with  want. I am all appetite. That's all  I do all day is want: food, the female  parts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth. I don't want a sermon  every time I ask a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the town's main drag now. There's a Chapel and next to it, a small house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God of misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to put her back where  she sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do that the Members will lynch me.  Consorting with a nigger, adultery,  siring a bastard while serving as  their preacher. We're a strict  congregation we've churched men for  picking up a fiddle on the sabbath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you reckoned to kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, Inman approaches the front door of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a back door. Have pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he leads Inman down a side path.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VEASEY HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Veasey comes in, now carrying the girl. Inman comes behin the gun trained on Veasey as he sets her down by the fire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Thank you. I was going to do a  grievous wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks longing at the girl as he puts the blanket aroun her shoulders. He turns to Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tasted dark meat? Sweet as  liquorice. I think I should go back  up to my wife. She wakes at the  slightest noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is incredulous that he thinks he can just go to bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find me some paper and a pen.

dialogues.speaker: INMAN HAS TIED A VERY DISTRAUGHT VEASEY TO A TREE IN FRON
dialogues.text: OF HIS CHAPEL. Inman is pinning a sheet of paper above  Veasey's head. It's covered in handwriting. A dog barks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not entitled to judge me!  You're nothing but an outlier, plain  as daylight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman has pulled a handkerchief from Veasey's jacket. He  stuffs it into his mouth, cutting this diatribe short. An then he walks away leaving Veasey tied to the tree, cursi through the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada asleep. Ruby enters, shattering the calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Pigs: you have any loose in  the woods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. What? No. We bought our hams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a world more to a hog than  the two hams! Lard, for example,  we'll need plenty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up some discarded laundry, contemplates the  overflowing laundry basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The catastrophe of Ada Monroe's  laundry. (marching out) I can feel you shutting your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada and Ruby working with the horse to make the beginning of A SPLIT RAIL FENCE. As they struggle with a heavy rail Ruby is testing Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this wood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Locust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's North?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North is, North is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name me three herbs growing wild on  this farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated with Ruby  and with herself) I can't! I can't! All right? I can  talk about farming in Latin. Will  that do? I can read French. I know  Harmony and Counterpoint. I know my  Bible. I can name the principal rivers  of Europe, but don't ask me to name  one stream in this county. I can  embroider, but I can't darn, I can  arrange cut flowers, but I can't  grow them. If a thing has a function,  if I might do something with it, it  wasn't considered suitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, you could ask why? about pretty  much everything to do with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They manage to get the first line of rail set down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fence is about the first thing  I've ever done that'll produce an  actual result.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you never wrapped your legs around  this Inman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-fashioned look from Ada...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUNKEN FOREST. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman finds himself in A SUNKEN FOREST OF PINE. He moves  warily, his beard longer, his figure gaunt, his clothes  weathering to a uniform smudge of charcoal. He hears DOGS BARKING IN THE DISTANCE, FAINT SHOUTS. He p up his pace, skirts round the swampy lake.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAPE FEAR RIVER. DUSK
dialogues.text: Inman comes to the bank of a HUGE RIVER. The water, as th light begins to go, is the color of mud, with bubbles,  belching to the surface, full of ugly prominent. Inman is almost jogging now, an ear tracking his still distant  pursuers. The river is too wide to contemplate swimming a now it begins to curve left, forcing him -- against his  judgment, to circle back. He approaches A SMALL JETTY. A sign: Ferry $5. Yell Loud. On the far bank there's A CABIN ON STILTS above the highw mark. Inman calls out, reluctantly, his voice still a kin of growl. Then again. A TINY FIGURE steps out of the cabin and waves before jum into a small canoe. The canoe heads against the current, rower's back bent with the effort. As the canoe approache Inman sees that the ferryman is, in fact, A YOUNG GIRL, n eighteen. She doesn't look at him. He produces five dolla She eyes the bill with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For five dollars I wouldn't give a  parched man a dipper of this  riverwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign says ferry, five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This look like a ferry? My Daddy's  dead, or gone off to the Federals,  don't matter which. I'm the way across  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but the mighty Cape Fear  River, is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog barks in the distance. Getting closer. Inman turns the sound. The Ferrygirl is well aware of her leverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody crosses this water unless  they're running from someplace. Some  cross one way, some the other: makes  no difference, they're all running.  You want to wait for your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you thirty dollars script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is astonished to see VEASEY stumble out of the tree His head is shaved, his face bruised and swollen, his clo castoffs and ill-fitting, cinched at the waist with rope. stumbles towards Inman, urging him to get on with the jou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going. We're both in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets straight into the canoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Homeguard. Made me tell them  all about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have shot you when I had  the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouts, more barking. Inman jumps in the canoe, and they' off. The Ferrygirl turns the boat around, rows them away  from the jetty with the grace of someone doing something the thousandth time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not looking for revenge, by the  way. For what you did to me. No, I'm  a Pilgrim now, like you, traveling  the road, paying our dues, relying  on the kindness of strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're nothing like me and the last  thing I want right now is a  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ferrygirl) You recall Job in the scriptures? I  will give free utterance to my  complaint. I will speak in the  bitterness of my soul. That's our  friend here... (to Inman) They cut off my hair. Which was hard.  I was vain about my hair. (to Ferrygirl) I had good curls. But I deserved it.  I'm the Reverend Veasey. Have I seen  you in church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman sits, scouring the bank for sign of his pursuers. T sun is sinking fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saving for a cowhide, and when I  get it I aim to get a saddle made,  and when I get me a saddle I'll save  for a horse, and when I got a horse  I'll throw on the saddle, and then  you won't see my sorry ass round  this swamp again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has no love for the river. Another gurgle of viscous  bubbles around the canoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catfish. 'gator. Keep your hand in  the boat. Already looks like some  critter chewed his neck. (she looks at Inman) Thirty more dollars, we can go to  the cabin. I'll pull this dress over  my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Have we got thirty dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sharp sound, a tiny thwack of ball on meat. The Ferrygi SUDDENLY SLUMPS BACK and falls into the water. Veasey grabs out at the oar, but it goes, too. The girl s quickly, A BLOODY GAP to the side of her head. Inman, on knees and stretching, can't help her. Then a second noise A HOLE THE SIZE OF A FIST appears in the canoe, just at  waterlevel. Water pours into the canoe. Dogs bark, and no FIGURES are visible at the jetty. HOME GUARD. One of them has a sniper's rifle and is loading for a third shot. Inm can see him sighting the rifle.
