They lie flat in the cano ANOTHER GREAT FIST OF WOOD is gouged out. Now the boat is almost full of water. Veasey spits out a foul mouthful. I ROCKS THE CANOE AND LETS IT TURN OVER ONTO THEM, Veasey  surfaces from under it, clutching the wood as a raft, but the canoe CATCHES INMAN A BLOW TO HIS HEAD and he sinks.  Veasey hauls him to the surface and, surprisingly strong, holds him with one fist, the boat with the other, lets th current take them, pulling them under, then up, under, th up, but clinging on, as the rifle continues to deliver it assault, another shot into the boat, another into the wat near to Veasey's arm. THE GIRL'S BODY comes by them, carried by the river, the  dress billowing out almost covering her head. The sun has gone, the light fading, the canoe sliding downriver away  from their aggressors.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAPE FEAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the moonlight, the canoe drifts into the muddy bank an Veasey drags a half-drowned Inman to land, both of them  retching with the vile river water. AN ALLIGATOR eases in the river not ten feet from where they lie, lungs heaving They get up. Veasey to his feet, Inman to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman nods, coughs. And Veasey AIMS A KICK at Inman's hea knocking him back into the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, god!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure that righteous, given our  history. Otherwise I'd bear a grudge  on our journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nowhere I'm going with you  except to Hellfire!

dialogues.speaker: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM. BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada, her hair plaited in a new and simpler configuration, working on Ruby's hair, while Ruby experiments with some  earrings. A pile of Ada's jewelry on the bed beside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agricola poetis viam non monstrat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmer does not point out the  road to a poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means? Should be the other way  round

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means, I suppose, which means  the poet should know where he's going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of Ada's hairdressing) It's no wonder you're helpless and  hopeless if it takes this long to  fix your hair. (of the Latin) Say some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terra mutata non mutat mores. (can't believe she  knows all these  phrases by heart) It's appalling what's in my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's appalling what's in my head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it means: A change of place does  not change a character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's surely true even in  English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can keep those earrings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't keep anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to keep the bangles. They  were my mother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's all. The rest is for  trading. Else they can bury you in  your finery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of her hair) You're done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a small mirror on a stand. It has Inman's picture stuck in it. She picks it up, removing the tintype, and  holding it up for Ruby to see her hairstyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God! Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the mirror and shows Ada her simple plait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes two minutes. That's what I  like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the earrings back in the pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you love that piano?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: THE PIANO jangles down the rutted lane on the back of Mr. Roy's cart. Ada watches, A SMALL FLOCK of sheep milling a her in the path. Ruby is dragging a big sow towards the y Ada picks up one of two sacks and staggers towards the ho

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: Ada arrives in the kitchen. They've got it under control  now, scrubbed and orderly. She puts the sack down next to another one. Her hands are calloused, the finger nails cr and ruined, stripes of earth under them. Ruby comes in,  struggling with the last sack, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're careful we'll get through the  winter now. I made old man Roy give  me ten of those sheep on account of  I said they were so small put together  they were no bigger than six proper  sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father always wanted sheep on  this land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you had to lose your piano.  I cut off my hair once, for money.  My daddy got two dollars for it.  Made a wig for a rich feller in  Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're working as they talk, taking the sacks into the  larder, putting out stuff for the evening meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stobrod called himself a musician --  my daddy -- he could play six tune  on a fiddle. Got himself shot dead  at Petersburg. I was like his goat  or some creature tethered to a post.  He left me once, up the mountains. I  was eight. He was gone over two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Ruby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defiant) I was all right! He'd walk forty  miles for liquor and not forty inches  for kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never met her. We're the same in  that regard. He said she was -- he  told me a thousand stories -- she  was a wolf or an indian or a donkey.  Don't say much for him, except you  know he'd be fast to work up a sweat  on a tree if he thought there was  pleasure in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pause. Ruby not easy with her emotions. Abruptl she jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's cows to milk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVER, EN ROUTE TO SALISBURY. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman stands in the river, hoping to catch a fish, trying concentrate. Veasey presides, complaining...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to be as regular as morning  prayers. Matter of fact I could set  my watch by my bowels. That beeswax  you fed me, day before yesterday, it  stops a man up. Open my gut now they'd  find turds stacked up like little  black twigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a parallel track across the river, RIDERS... impossibl to say whether Home Guard or a Federal Raiding Party. Inm splashes out of the water, pushes Veasey down, silencing  him. The riders pass. Veasey spots something shining in the grass, picks it up. IT'S A LONG TWO-HANDED SAW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Look at this! (flexing it) This is a good saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) It's not yours. You take it, you  make us another enemy. You're a  Christian -- don' t you know your  commandments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find the good Lord very  flexible on the subject of property.  We could do a lot with this saw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is vexed, walks away. Veasey follows, experimenting with the saw's music when flexed. Inman stalks on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEAR A FORD. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman way ahead, full of purpose. Veasey still has the sa trots to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you in such a hurry the whole  time? (no answer) Hurry or slow the destination is  always the same. It's only the journey  that is different. That's either in  the Good Book or I made it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman suddenly stops, scowling, puts up a hand, listens. Inman carefully scouts the track then, with great caution edges towards the river bank. A HEAVY SET MAN labours in the water. He's contemplating HUGE BLACK CARCASS OF A BULL which has slipped into the f and died. The man is wet and exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man turns, his spirit evidently lifted by the prospec of help. His name is JUNIOR. He's working on roping the  animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My old bull, wandered off and died  in this here creek. Fouled up our  water is how I found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veasey is immediately an authority on bull removal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a tricky one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men contemplate the carcass, swatting away the  swarms of flies. Junior offers a swig from a jug of liquo Inman refuses, Veasey takes a long pull, shudders happily

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name for the Bull's member is a  tassel. I learned that and never  forgot it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon I need a train of mules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away) I'm getting an idea. My saw is the  remedy. Let's saw up some wood and  make levers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lever him out. This'll work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into the wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you two sports heading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inscrutable) I don't know where he's heading. I'm  going down the road. And I got a  good way to go before nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acknowledging his  attitude) Charitable of you to make a stop.  Ain't for me to be curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emerges from the  woods) How do you work this damn thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Veasey) Give me that saw. (to Junior) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the saw, walks to the bull, gets on one side,  indicates Junior should go to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do this in chapters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they begin to SAW OFF THE BULL'S NECK. LATER, and they're in A VILE STEW OF BLOOD AND INNARDS. T stomach opens and its contents gush into the creek. Vease is disgusted, draws back. The two other men haul up the r of the animal onto the banks. They're exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to leave off that  water for a day or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be a tang, I'd imagine.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRACK APPROACHING JUNIOR'S CABIN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Junior, Inman and Veasey come around a bend and there's A BIG CABIN LOOMING. It's in such poor repair that one end slipped from the stones which serve as it's foundation an STANDS BADLY TILTED OVER. Junior roots up another hidden of liquor, which he drinks from, then hands to Veasey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's my place. Hope you can stomach  a yard chock-full of females. Brought  my woman home, she showed up with  her three so-called sisters and their  brats. The noise in that place is  something awful. It's why I go  hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considering the wild  camber) Looks a bit crooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is on a bit of a tilt. Them  females. They all roll down one end  each night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Roll me over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- In the clover

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One good fart -- that'll tip over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They guffaw, delighted in the alcohol haze. Veasey sudden exclaims, hand in the air, rushes into the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God of my God! Hallelujah!  Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Israelites! The tribes of Israel  are about to flee from the banks of  Egypt! Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining to Junior) He's got a shit coming on. It's  overdue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) And he's a Preacher? Like a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUNIOR'S CABIN. DUSK
dialogues.text: The three men arrive at the yard. DOGS AND CHILDREN MILL  AROUND THE VISITORS. FOUR WOMEN COME OUT, one after the o each of them in simple shifts which seem to emphasis thei voluptuousness, or so it seems to Veasey. They freely sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These two boys is stopping for supper.  They're on the road to Atonement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women consider the men, then disappear back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atonement is not a place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it when it's at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are fine examples of the female.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take them all and leave the saw. Be  a sight more use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reappearing) If they want to get in a tub there's  an hour before food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They love to scrub a man. (to Shyla) Put the water on the boil. (back to the men) It's my liquor, gets their titties  swinging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) God damn! (to Inman) I was right about sheep droppings  those stools -- like rock hard. Quite  astonishing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMOKEHOUSE AT JUNIOR'S CABIN. DUSK
dialogues.text: No real furniture. Veasey is shaving. Inman stows his kna behind the woodburning stove, on which a big kettle of bo water steams away. Then he gets in the tub, his back to t door. Shyla comes in, brings the kettle over to the tub, pours the steaming water. She appraises Inman. It's intensely  sexual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's battered flesh. (of his neck wound) I could work a finger in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a hero. Took that wound at  Petersburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know what I am. (uncomfortable with  her stare) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Veasey) He's shy, ain't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait up a few minutes, I'll be in  that tub, then we'll see who's a shy  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to poke my thumb in his holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second woman comes to the door. Dolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila says supper's up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JUNIOR'S CABIN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: LILA, JUNIOR'S WIFE, spoons out stew from a vast pot. The table crammed with customers -- her three sisters, the th men, the herd of dogs and filthy children. Nobody speaks. Each time Lila bends over to spoon out of the pot, her  cleavage strains against the flimsy fabric of her dress.  Veasey's mesmerized. Inman is also getting drunk, his eye increasingly glazed. When Lila makes to sit down next to  Junior, he slides a hand up her dress, exposing a naked  buttock, which he strokes and pinches as he pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior grins, looks over at Inman, then nudges Veasey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone now. Look! His eyes have  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely, drunk) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae. That's a  poem. That's a poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to recite, has a verse in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae (but he can' t summon  it) Da-da da-da da-da dae... (vague) ...there's a poem there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving soon as I'm full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a bunch of traps needs visiting.  I'll be back tomorrow, before dark.  You'll still be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my fervent prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My house is your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Like to wash their hands and pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, Lila, Shyla and Mae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Job. Don't say much but even  liquored up there's a preacher in  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman gets up suddenly, sways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say my goodbyes, got miles and  miles to go before sunset. (head spinning) I'll just quickly lie down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he stumbles over to the fire where he instantly curls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm heading for that smokehouse and  I'm ready to be washed clean of my  dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, wanders out of the door. Junior's eyes glint. jerks his head towards the girls then in the direction of the smokehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go tend to him. (to Lila) I'll be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his gun and leaves Dolly gathering up the chi and herding them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on you -- get!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shyla stays, Mae having gone off after Veasey. Lila waits until the children have gone. They consider Inman supine the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's mine. You can go rub yourself  off on the Preacher. (of Inman) Gonna make him hug me till I grunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila shepherds Shyla out, shuts the door, swigs from the  jug, walks over to Inman, then turns to the big table and pushes pots and plates way down to one end to make a play field. Then she bends over the prostrate Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman stirs, glazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneeling down to him) You want to see what Mamma's got for  you?

dialogues.speaker: SHE SLIPS A SLEEVE OF HER DRESS TO REVEAL A FULL BREAST.
dialogues.text: Inman is drunk, doesn't think he's awake. She takes her b to his mouth, and Inman suckles. Then she puts his hands  under the dress which rides up as his hands move between legs. She's naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. Ain't that sweet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just get on and ride me all the  way to China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't move, except to sway, eyes glazed. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shy? You need a hand? (goes to his buttons) Let's have a look see what we can  muster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's kneeling now, her dress hunched up around her middl working the front of Inman's pants. He's in a swoon,  surrendering to her, getting aroused, his hand cupping he head. ON CUE, THE DOOR CRASHES OPEN AND HE'S STARING DOWN THE BARREL OF JUNIOR'S SHOTGUN. As Lila turns, Junior KICKS HER violently in the head,  knocking her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little bitch! Look at you! Cover  yourself up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEAD. Inman falls back. Junior goes to the door and whist

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMOKEHOUSE AT JUNIOR'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Lila enters the smokehouse, hand to her bruised head. VEA

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FLOOR, WITH DOLLY ASTRIDE HIM, HIS ARM CRUSHING A
dialogues.text: NAKED MAE INTO AN EMBRACE. He considers Lila, beams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a special prayer you'd come  visit.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUNIOR'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Veasey led out, a CHAIN GANG waiting -- a bedraggled  collection of prisoners, slaves, deserters -- and now INM Veasey is joined to the line. It starts to rain.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby and Ada at the door of the Swanger house. They both  wear Monroe's clothes by now, like two little men. THEY'R CARRYING A SMALL SACK, A PIE UNDER A CLOTH. Ruby hammers the door, a little impatient. Sally Swanger opens it, has decode who it is under the clothes, the hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada Monroe and Ruby Thewes! Look at  you both!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at us both what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a coupla scarecrows after a  thunderstorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a scarecrow, birds eating up  half our winter garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally's right. We should both stop  toiling and stand a while with our  arms stretch out. I'll volunteer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For all your kindness. Coffee. And a  pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's real coffee. It ain't hickory  and dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the gifts) Thank you both. (of the pie) Ruby, I look forward to this. We all  do. Esco and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning at Ada) She made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God in Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by way of  recommendation) I'm still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally's strangely awkward, lingering at the door, staring the gifts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be getting along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) I know Esco's going to be real sorry  he missed you. You all take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all kiss, then the girls walk back down the path. Ru is vexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That strike you as odd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stood at her front door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one -- I know that woman all  my life. I never stood outside her  house -- she'd invite a wolf inside  if it knocked on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, I don't know, perhaps she  was busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number two -- Old Man Swanger was  inside that house: I could smell his  pipe burning. Number three -- look  at these fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She contemplated the stubble fields they're passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came by here a week ago, they  were waist high in hay.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A PATH. DRIVING RAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Home Guard ride, bent under their oilskins, as the ra tips down. Between the horses, unprotected and drenched,  their prisoners trudge along the muddy path. Inman and Ve among them. Veasey has grown some beard. AN OLDER MAN COLLAPSES, lies where he falls, not moving. There's a domino effect and so Inman falls on top of him. picks himself up, then tries to pull up the older man. He doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses plough on. Inman shouts to BROWN, the leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man's dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody pays any attention. He has to drag the body.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOME GUARD ESCORT THE PRISONERS PAST VEASEY'S OLD CHU
dialogues.text: More days have gone by and taken their toll on the prison Veasey and Inman are haggard and filthy and reduced. The  Home Guards stop for food, a wash, a break, chain the  prisoners to a horse rail. Citizens go by, Veasey knows them all. Some of them spit  contemptuously at the Deserters. None of them recognise  Veasey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I so altered that they don't see  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody walks by with a young child. Veasey looks at Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I christened that child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child stops, looks without recognizing, is tugged awa from the chain gang by his mother. One of the other priso SHEFFIELD, leans in to Inman, his voice low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking to get out of this. They  drag us back to fight -- we're just  target practice for the Federal boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You run, we're all running with you,  the lame and the stupid, of which we  number both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either way we're fucked. Run or don't  run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me some warning so I can  tell the guard -- I'm not getting  shot again for some cause I don't  believe in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP OF SLAVES ARE WALKING BY, CARRYING SACKS. One of women is pregnant. Veasey studies the group, sees the pre woman, recognizes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mesmerized) That's Rebecca. That's Rebecca. (he hisses) Rebecca!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In daylight it's apparent that Rebecca is a real beauty. turns at the sound of her name, stops, is confused. She s Veasey and approaches, appalled at his condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it well with you? (Rebecca nods) I've been repenting for what I did.  I've walked the road of atonement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your curls is all gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding his head, to  Rebecca) God Bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca, reluctant, rejoins the other slaves, walks away  with them, but then turns back to look at Veasey. She cle cares about him. And seeing her has somehow broken his he He turns away from Inman, towards Sheffield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with you. I got a baby coming.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILROAD TRACK. DAY
dialogues.text: THE CHAIN GANG TRUDGES DOWN THE TRACK, horses on either s of them, steep banks forming a V for the railroad. A TRAI IS COMING. Brown rides up to the prisoners, herds them of the track. The train approaches quite slowly -- the boxca full of wounded soldiers. Some of the Home Guard dismount take out pipes. The prisoners wait, one of them sits down Sheffield says something to Veasey, who casually yanks up the sitting prisoner. Inman suddenly understands what's g to happen. The train is almost on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's too late. SHEFFIELD JERKS FORWARD IN FRONT OF TH TRAIN, PULLING ALL THE OTHERS WITH HIM, their reluctance  tempered by the possibility of being crushed by the oncom train. SOMEHOW THE CHAIN GANG GETS ACROSS THE TRACK, stumbling a chaotic, the chains yanking tight, then loose, the tight  causing a collapse, the loose a recovery. They run alongside the train, blocking themselves from th fire of the Guard, Sheffield screaming tactics -- and the as the train starts to pull past them, they run up the ba now all as a unit scrambling to the steep summit.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TRAIN THE HOME GUARD HAVE REMOUN
dialogues.text: THEIR HORSES AND ARE RIDING HARD ALONGSIDE IT. Then they  have sight of the escaping prisoners silhouetted at the t of the bank like a line of paper dolls stretched out alon the ridge. Sheffield's yelling with adrenaline, Veasey jo in, elated. One of the guards raises a rifle, steadies hi on his horse, FIRES. He catches Veasey, who crumples, spi round and falling down the bank, until Inman uses all his strength and practically lifts him in the air. The chain  recovers and works back up the bank. But then A SECOND BULLET catches another prisoner and thi time the effect is catastrophic -- THE WHOLE GANG JUST FL OVER AND PLUMMETS DOWN THE BANK. The Home Guard approach, firing randomly at the bodies as they tumble into the dit by the side of the track. Until all movement ceases. Inma has a wound to his head which bleeds profusely, almost  completely covering his face. Brown arrives, considers th carnage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get these sacks of shit under the  ground.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAWN
dialogues.text: Ada's milking. It's barely daylight. She's slowly becomin country girl. Ruby appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's been in the corncrib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a coon or possum. Scratched out  a fist hole in the side. This place!  I'm telling you -- we grow, others  eat. I'll go into town, take the  last of the cider and trade for a  trap.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MONROE'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada is in Monroe's bedroom, looks out as Ruby goes off to town, jugs of cider swung either side of the horse. Ada g over to Monroe's closet, pulls out some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WINTER GARDEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada buttons Monroe's dress coat and completes the SCARECR she's spent the day making, save for the hat, which she n fixes on, pushing in a hat pin to secure it. She's made a stern black thing and steps back to consider it. Horsemen come riding along the lane. It's Teague and his  men. He doesn't stop but raises his hat to Ada.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada looks out at the Winter Garden. From that distance it really does look like her father out in the field, arms  outstretched as if waiting for her to run to him. She fin it unbearable, her tears coming, runs out into the fields attacks the scarecrow, pulling off the hat, the clothes..

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILROAD TRACK. MORNING
dialogues.text: THE SOUND OF TINY BELLS. A misty drizzle. A GOAT snuffles around in the freshly turned dirt: A hand, pale and wet,  protrudes from the thin layer of earth covering the bodie of the murdered Chain Gang. SOMETHING SHIFTS UNDER THE DIRT, breaking the surface. In wedged under three or four corpses -- their limbs and cha wrapped around him, has regained consciousness. He coughs can't breathe properly, tries to work himself some air,  spitting out dirt. He makes a noise to distract the goat, rattling the chains. Inman rears up, the bodies slitherin off him, but even then the animal only retreats a yard or two. VEASEY SLIDES FACE UP, A BULLET IN HIS FOREHEAD LIKE MYSTICAL THIRD EYE. Inman feels a surprising loss and  tenderness. He heaves again, groaning with the pain of ne and old wounds.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby rides back from town along the river. An ugly lookin trap tied over the horses and three or four bulging sacks By an abandoned mill she sees the Home Guard under the tr She slows up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you looking to catch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got some critter stealing our  corn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still but the two of you up there,  is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we get a cold night, camped  out, trying to keep the rule of law,  protecting girls like you from  Federals and deserters, that's a  thought warms us (to his men) ain't it? -- the two of you up there  on my Grand-daddy's farm, dressed in  men's clothes. Warms us right up.  What you got in the sacks? (to the men) Looks like human heads! Eh? Looks  like a bunch of heads. We got  competition!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby rides on. She rides around the bend -- she's not far from the Swanger farm.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILROAD TRACK. DAY
dialogues.text: Goats, their bells tinkling, munch around the tracks. One them turns at a noise -- a GROTESQUE VISION -- A MOVING,  SEETHING MOUND OF DIRT. It's Inman, inching along the  embankment, the chain of dead bodies in tow, a macabre tu of war. He considers the goats, they consider him. He rea up and finds himself STARING DOWN THE BARREL OF A SHOTGUN

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Sally is pinning out white sheets, they're filling out li sails in the afternoon wind. Ruby rides up. Sally seems a little vexed to see her. She walks down to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not stopping, Sally. I'm not  snooping neither. Just you should  know Teague and his boys are lurking  down by Pigeon River, the old mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) You tell Ada that was a good pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby rides off. Sally watches, then goes inside the house her energy changing immediately, as if she might faint.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: HARSH WHISTLES. A secret place, in the heart of a forest. There's the answering sound of SMALL BELLS, a chorus of t Inman is dragged into view on a makeshift litter. Goats  appear, they herd around the figure dragging the litter.  IT'S AN OLD WOMAN, silver haired, her face a leather map, her clothes leather, everything about her like old leathe HER NAME IS MADDY. She and Inman round a bend and there's Maddy's house -- A OLD CARAVAN, long grown into the ground and plaited with  vines and creepers. Inman tries to sit up. An old whisker BILLYGOAT butts up against Inman, knocks him down. Maddy  pays no attention to the struggle, heads inside her carav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind that Billy, he's the jealous  kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She emerges, with a bowl of water, rags, washes his face, pushing back his hair to look at his wound, puts a finger the gash on his neck professional in her appraisal. Inman barely conscious, he groans, trying to defend himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay no attention to me. What happened  to your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the color of a cadaver. I'll  fix you. I can fix you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking of his spirit) Mister -- you could fix me I'd be in  your everlasting debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debts, fighting -- them words don't  mean much round here. For the record,  I'm a female of the species.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby rides up to the farm. She rides past the winter gard admires THE SCARECROW -- WHICH NOW PARODIES ADA, the same outfit she once wore to visit Inman, the same dress, same hat. Ruby grins as Ada comes over from the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hat's a nice touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby gets off the horse, and they start unloading sacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cried for my Daddy. I dressed up  the scarecrow in his suit and he  came back, his arms out, said you  never cried enough, you never cried  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I thought, it's not my Daddy,  it's my sweetheart. I saw him once  that way, when I looked down Sally's  well. So I dressed the scarecrow in  the dress I wore the day he left. In  case his spirit flies over looking  out for me. (of the vicious looking  trap) That looks terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby opens the sacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabbages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bargained like Lucifer. We can  make all kinds of good eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabbage. Slaw, sauerkraut, cabbage  soup, fried cabbage, stuffed  cabbage...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: TEAGUE'S MEN RIDE UP TO THE FARM. Esco's out in the field labouring away, but with his shotgun by him. Teague stops alongside the field, the rail between him and Esco. Esco  stops working, picks up his shotgun and goes over. Teague has four men with him. MO and JO, the twins, huge, and wi the appearance of having less than one brain between the of them, GRAYLING, a reluctant-looking man, funereal in h bearing, and BOSIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The riders slowly fan out, almost as if choreographed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't spread out. Why they spreading  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not spreading out. I'm sitting  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esco comes over the rail fence, his gun loose in his hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never knew a man worked in his field  with a shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a war on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to watch out for the Bogey Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to fish out a tobacco pouch. Esco's gun swings Teague shows him the leather pouch, shrugs, starts to mak cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: From inside the house, Sally watches everything. Her view impaired by the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mo dismounts. Ambles past Esco, looks behind the sheets.  ESCO KICKS OUT AT HIM, the shotgun rigid and pointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off my land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo examines his breeches for a dust mark, wipes it off,  retreating in a turkey walk of examining and dusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boys come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't seen my boys in four years.  They're fighting other boys, not old  men and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) He means us. He's referring there to  us. (to Esco) So you won't care if we take a look  around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I gotta give you? A chicken? A  lamb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing is -- you got one barrel and  there's five of us. Not a fair fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bogey Man! Bogey Man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esco is momentarily distracted and, in that instant, Mo k out at him, knocking the gun from his hands, which fires  into the air, a shocking sound.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby and Ada digging a trench by the smokehouse, laying i the pale heads of cabbage. They hear the distant shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop. Listen. Look at each other, start running.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Jo sets on Esco, knocking him-backwards into a sheet, whe it gets twisted, while Jo kicks and punches, little spots blood staining the sheet with each blow. MO PULLS OUT HIS

dialogues.speaker: ESCO TO THE SHEET, THEN SPINNING HIM ROUND IN THE SHEET S
dialogues.text: THAT IT TIGHTENS. A stain grows out from the blade, huge spreading. Teague walks to Esco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're harbouring deserters. I can  confiscate every animal on this farm,  every plate, every sheet, every little  pellet of chicken shit -- I can  confiscate your old lady's asshole,  so don't offer me a bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally runs out, screaming. She tries to pull out the sabr MO REVERSES HIS RIFLE AND CLUBS HER TO THE GROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo backs away. Sally is screaming. She watches, helpless, Esco dies in front of her, the sheet growing a darker red

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got your bait. Set it on the  hook.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARN, SWANGER FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: ELLIS AND ACTON SWANGER emerge from their hiding places,  unable to bear the sound of their mother's screams. They' carrying an axe, a pitchfork, mad for revenge.

dialogues.speaker: BOSIE IS DOING SOME SORT OF DANCE ALONG THE FENCE RAIL. H
dialogues.text: very graceful, his hair flying, his hands out, one finger nail extremely long, his boots stamping down on the fence

dialogues.speaker: UNDER HIS STOMPING FEET, THE RAIL POST IS PRESSED ON SALL
dialogues.text: SWANGER'S THUMBS. She can't scream any longer, because th noose has practically strangled her. The rope's tied off Bosie's horse, which yanks on the noose with every slight movement. Sally is prostrate in the dirt. Her two boys come running from the barn. TEAGUE CASUALLY,

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: Ada and Ruby, riding together on the horse, arrive at the Swangers. SALLY IS STILL PINNED UNDER THE FENCE POST. The noose aro her neck has been tied off to the post so that she can't  move. There's a bloody sheet draped over the edge of the  well. Blood on the ground. Ruby heaves at the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get this damn thing off her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the well, looking  down) Dear Lord in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada, I can't get this off her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada runs over. They struggle, can't lift it. Sally's lips are moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What darling? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bends down, listens to her. Looks up at Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's saying don't bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs a thick log off the stack, staggers back and in second they've inserted it into the fence and levered it and away from Sally's hands. They fall back onto the dirt Ruby cradles Sally. Ada nods towards the well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's someone down there. I think  it's Esco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby looks over at the well, then at Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This world won't stand long. God  won't let it stand this way long.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. DAY
dialogues.text: An exotic interior, many crocks and jars, bunches of herb wrapped papers of dried things, like a woodland apothecar store. Inman wakes up. He finds himself in a small cot,  wrapped in blankets, a poultice at his neck. He doesn't k where he is or how long he's been there.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. DAY
dialogues.text: Maddy's sitting on a stool. There's a circle of stones wh her fire lives and she sets the tinder to it. Inman emerg from the caravan. He's pale and unsteady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I been sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stop here. I'm a deserter.  They find me here things could be  bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they going to do? Cut short my  young life? Sit down before you fall  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She calls over a little goat. It ambles over affectionate and nuzzles into her hand. She strokes it and scratches u the chin. The creature gets increasingly tranquil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What year are we? '63?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time I checked it was '64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say twenty six years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty six years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could move on anytime. I've seen  most of the world anyway, Richmond  in the North, south almost to  Charleston. You're going somewhere  or you are somewhere, what's the  difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still stroking the goat. It looks as if it's asleep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've learned a person can survive  off pretty much of a goat. I can't  abide a chicken, but a goat gives  you company and milk and cheese and  then, when you need it, good meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a single motion she has a knife in her hand and has SL THE THROAT OF THE GOAT, putting the bowl underneath its n to catch the blood, still stroking the goat, which blinks if it were only surprised and not dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you've been fighting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he might break) I could be at killing for days  sometimes, in the hand to hand, my  feet against the feet of my enemy  and I always killed him and he never  killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave it a try, to look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See I think there's a plan. There's  a design. For each and every one of  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this she's shucked the skin off the goat with the  authority of someone who's done this a thousand times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look at nature, a bird flies  somewhere, picks up a seed, shits  the seed out, a plant grows. Bird's  got a job, seed's got a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the goat is now thin and pink, eyes bulging, a piece meat.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MADDY'S CARAVAN. EVENING
dialogues.text: A woodburning stove with a single cooking plate -- on whi pieces of the goat meat, sprinkled with herbs, are sizzli in a pan.

dialogues.speaker: INMAN IS EATING LIKE A MAN POSSESSED, WRAPPING THE MEAT I
dialogues.text: CORN FRITTERS AND PUSHING THEM INTO HIS MOUTH. Maddy watc him, adds another mound of meat to his plate. Inman nods thanks, but -- doesn't look up. She opens a jar and takes out a handful of dried poppy he puts them near the stove, then dips into another jar and  pulls out what look like old cheroot stubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take one of these now with your food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is circumspect, views the stub lozenge with suspici

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swallow it. If you die I'll give you  your money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman puts it in his mouth, gags at the taste of it. She  hands him a beaker with milk to wash it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our minds aren't made to hold on to  the particulars of pain, the way we  do bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts steaming the poppies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada. (At the food) -- Sometimes I think I'm crazy when  I'm just hungry -- (another mouthful) Ada Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And is she waiting for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was. I don't know. Or if she'd  know me. I'm like the boy who goes  out in winter for firewood comes  back in the spring with a whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy pricks open the poppies and collects their opium, t hands Inman the liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now drink this. It visits the pain.  And you'll sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks the laudanum she's made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had to put myself in the way of  people's kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dips a cloth in the steaming water, unbuttons his shi She has a crock of what looks like treacle and vaseline. smears this salve over the neck wound and into his scalp. Inman surrenders to the drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passenger pigeons fly south, the  berries ripen. Whether I see them or  not, whether a man dies, or a war is  won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the laudanum getting to you.  That's good. Say something more. (she kneels to his  leg) Raise that up for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He obliges. She grimaces at the state of it, where the ch has chewed into the flesh. Gets to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gave me a book. Ada Monroe. Man  by the name of Bartram. Wrote about  his travels. I carried that book  through every battle. I left it  someplace, got to get it back.  Sometimes just reading the name of a  place near home -- Sorell Cove, Fire  Scale Ridge -- was enough to bring  me to tears. Thing is I've been  thinking -- those places belonged to  people before us, to the Indian --  and he had a different name. What  did he call Sorell Cove? How can a  name not even the real name break  your heart? It's her, she's the place  I'm heading. And I hardly know her.  So how can a person who's maybe not  even a real person -- I don't know  what I'm talking about -- I have to  close my eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides off the stool and lays on the floor. Maddy goes over to her cot and pulls off a blanket which she drapes  over him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada in the henhouse, collecting eggs, is confident now am the birds. She emerges to find Ruby walking out of the  backdoor with the shotgun and a determined look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raiding our corn. Got him in the  trap. That's him yelping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to shoot him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want him to shoot me. (of the gun) Can you fire this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making it clear she  can't) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head towards the corn crib, bundled up against the c A MAN IS KNEELING AT THE CORN CRIB, perfectly caught in t art of stealing, his head forced away from view. Ruby han Ada the gun and approaches, warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up -- you got a barrel trained  on your rear-end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out of this dang thing. My  fist's about to drop off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a weapon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am. I'm begging you. I'm already  on my knees, otherwise I'd get down  on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly recognises  the voice) Unbelievable! Stobrod Thewes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby? God damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ada, disgusted) That's my daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks up to him and KICKS HIM HARD AS SHE CAN ON HIS  BACKSIDE.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: A strip of fabric, homemade bandage, being wrapped around Stobrod's badly gashed hand. Ada is tending to him. Ruby cooking at the range, not remotely warm towards her prodi father, who looks rather comfortable. Stobrod looks at he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so's you know -- I can eat while  she's doing this -- in case you're  holding off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so's you know -- you're not  eating inside. Number One -- they  hang people round here for taking in  deserters. Number two -- even if  they gave out prizes -- you'd still  eat outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scarred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your heart. Scarred. I did wrong to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be scarred. You'd be really  scarred if I hadn't wrapped them  trap teeth in sacking. Which was her  idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote fifty tunes with you in mind.  Ruby this, Ruby that, Ruby with the  eyes that sparkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Let's agree: you beat me, you  abandoned me, you ignored me, you  beat me some more -- all of that is  better than Ruby with the eyes that  sparkle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm changed. People change. War  changes people something terrible. (to Ada) Ruby's told you -- I've no doubt --  I wasn't always the best...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't disagree with that. I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music's changed me. I'm full of music,  darling. I wish I'd brung my fiddle  Hey Ruby! Got a new fiddle -- it's  got a little snake's rattle in the  body -- took it off a dead federal  in Virginia. That's a beautiful  fiddle. It's full of tunes, Ruby.  Don't know if it's from that little  rattle locked up in it, or from  something untied my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby walks over with a crock, wrapped in a cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Bless you both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you got a proper coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, I'm fine. And you just say  the word, I won't come back neither.  I don't want to put either you or  your mistress here in any bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not Ruby's employer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, who is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. (Stobrod digests this) I'll make up food for you, you come  Sundays before it's light, I'll leave  it behind the Old Frazier Mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who really needs a coat,  darling, is my partner, fat boy name  of Pangle. We're hiding up in the  caves and he feels the cold like a  thin man, but ain't no coat'll fit  him. (leaving) I love you, Ruby. In case the sky  falls on our head. You're a good  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's gone. Ruby scowls. FIDDLE MUSIC BEGINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is so full of manure, that man,  we could lay him on the dirt and  grow another one just like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's Stobrod Thewes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is and that's the last you'll see  of him.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIDDLE CONTINUES, A BANJO JOINS IN.
dialogues.text: Maddy is loading up Inman for his journey. She hands him bulging goatskin satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's medicine and goatmeat. You're  sick of both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a deal to thank you for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him an ancient flintlock pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's just for show, or -- if  you can get close enough -- a wild  turkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, abruptly, mingles in with her goats. Inman nod knows that she doesn't want a fuss, although he wants to  make one, and turns himself, heads away from the caravan.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS. DAY
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. A TURKEY calls. And again. JUNIOR is hunting. He creeps through this clearing, eyes  peeled for the turkey, gun at the ready. His dog growls, he puts a hand over its mouth. He listens. Another call. Junior moves, without sound, in its direction, stops for  several seconds under a tree, listening. He looks up. INM IS PERCHED IN THE TREE. THE PISTOL FLASHES IN HIS HAND.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUNIOR'S CABIN. DAY
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. Inman drags Junior's corpse in to th yard. The dogs whine and slobber over the body. Inman goe straight into the Smoke House.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMOKE HOUSE AT JUNIOR'S CABIN. DAY
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. Inman reaches behind the stove and  retrieves his bag. He checks for the LeMats, for the Bart opens it, locating the tintype of Ada, which he considers as the dogs howl outside, joined with another wailing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUNIOR'S CABIN. DAY
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. Inman emerges with his bag, LeMats a the ready. The women are all keening over the corpse, as a saint had passed away. Dogs, women all howling. A chick bobs in, investigates the glob of blood on Junior's skull Inman walks away, doesn't look at the women, who don't lo at him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RUBY'S ROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAWN
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. Ruby wakes up. Looks out of the wind Ada, also woken, comes into Ruby's room. STOBROD IS OUTSI WITH PANGLE, VIOLIN AND BANJO. Ruby opens the window,  scowling. Stobrod beams, stops playing, holds up the food points at Pangle in his new coat. Pangle waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on back where you came from!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stobrod and Pangle smile and hurry away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PATH IN HILL COUNTRY. DAY
dialogues.text: WINTER SETTING IN. Inman, increasingly a stick figure in landscape, wasted and fragile, trudges along through fall leaves. He still limps from the leg irons. No shelter  anywhere. He unwraps a paper containing some scraps of go meat and corn bread. He walks and eats, fishes out a loze tries to swallow it, washes it down with a drink from his flask. Opens the crock of salve and rubs the treacly grea into his neck and ankle. The path splits. He doesn't know which way to go, A CROW repeatedly caws off to the left a taking it as a sign, Inman goes in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My love for Heathcliff resembles the  eternal rocks beneath

dialogues.speaker: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada in the bed, reading to Ruby from Wuthering Heights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a source of little visible delight,  But necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't gonna marry Linton, is  she? She said -- whatever our souls  are made of his and mine are the  same. You can't say that and then  marry Linton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not waiting until tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, I'm falling asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lies back in her bed. Ruby takes the book, lies acros the bottom of the bed, as Ada goes to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little visible delight, but necessary.  I like that...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SMALL WOOD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: DRIVING RAIN. Inman shelters under a huge tree, whose spl trunk provides a mean shelter. He inserts himself into th cleft of it, a black thing in a black tree, like a troll. stands, shivers, sodden, desolate.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A LITTLE CABIN. Its lights coming through square windows  like a chinese lantern. Inman considers it, the risk vers the shelter. The sleet still pelts down on him and he decides to appro Closer he can hear a sound coming from the house. IT'S A

dialogues.speaker: QUILT.
dialogues.text: Inman knocks hard on the door. The light from the lamp go out, although the fire still gives the room a clear glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm one man alone. I'm a Confederate  soldier on furlough. I have no bad  intention. I need shelter and food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I at least sleep in the corn  crib -- just for some shelter? I'll  be on my way come morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Inman accepts this as a rebuttal, and trudges  back towards the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman turns. A gap in the door appears, the figure barely seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby's crying behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some beans and corn pone,  all I got. You better come in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Inman enters the cabin. It's a single room. A big fire. T baby on the bed, a rudimentary crib unoccupied next to it The woman is already at the little stove. She turns to hi She's painfully beautiful. But sad and fragile. Inman, de himself, is mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alone here, as you can see, with  my baby. I need to believe you mean  no harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman takes out his gun. She starts, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean to give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns it handle forwards and offers it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it. I had my way they'd  take metal altogether out of this  world. Every blade, every gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your baby sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cries. I don't know. He cries a  lot. My man is dead. He took his  wound at Fredericksburg. Never saw  his boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never once looks at him. Her eyes on the floor or the food or the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty much what you'll get if  you knock on any door of this war.  Man dead, woman left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a plate of steaming beans. An onion perched top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mean food but it's hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes over to the bed and picks up her baby and starts the same business of walking him, singing the while, an o lament. Inman eats, looks at her, at the child and the fi He picks up the onion, bites into it. Sara looks across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ashamed of his hunger) There's no hunting on the road, just  cress and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes another bite. Sara picks up the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to feed this man, if you could  look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman, embarrassed, turns his back to her. He sits finish the food while she puts the baby to her breast, slipping shoulder from her dress. While the baby feeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to have a cow, few goats. Raiders  took them. Made me kill our own dog  on the porch. That poor creature  watched over me. Nothing left now  save a hog and couple of chickens to  live off till spring. I'll have to  kill that hog and make sense of the  flesh and divisions which is something  I never did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could do that for you in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what I'd gladly do for you for  what you're gladly doing for me. I'm  Inman by the way. That's my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sara. My baby's Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to know you both.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sara walks ahead of Inman. She carries a pile of clothing pair of boots. It's still wretched outside, she hugs the  house, the porch barely offering shelter. INMAN FOLLOWS,  with a bowl of steaming water and a small towel over his  arm. She hands him the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look about his size. He was  another man straight up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a palpable attraction between them, so that every exchange seems to contain a promise, a sexual charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even have a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll leave you the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the dim light, Inman peels off his clothes, sets to wo with the bar of soap and the cloth to scrub himself clean He can be seen from the window and finds himself turning  away to pull off his pants.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sara sits at the cot, still singing to the baby, then get up, goes to the window, sees Inman dressing, walks to the door, lets it open a little, but not so as she can be see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much. These boots are good  boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Inman settles down into the corncrib. He's cold and every is damp and lumpy and uncomfortable. He pulls his thin bl around him. The wind is howling. He levers himself up, lo at the house with its warm invitation, can almost feel Sa in there. He reluctantly settles down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you come inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands in a shift, a blanket over her shoulders. Her  body under the cotton very clear to him. She turns and go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SARA'S CABIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Inman comes in. Sara is sitting on her bed. Long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you do something for me? Do  you think you could lie here, next  to me, and not need to go further?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on the bed as she slips under the covers, and the removes the boots, his shirt, gets under the covers. Ther an electric space between them. Then Sara begins to cry,  pulls his arm to open up so that she can be folded into h SHE SOBS, SHUDDERING IN THE BED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go. I'll go, shall I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie, staring up at the ceiling, her tears falling. A FIDDLE PLAYS HEAVY WITH YEARNING...

dialogues.speaker: INT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. CHRISTMAS DAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC CONTINUES. Stobrod is playing the fiddle, his b hand still lightly taped and a fingerless mitten covering it. They're in the abandoned Mill, a derelict space, whic has been cheered up with some rudimentary Christmas  decorations. Ada, Ruby and Sally Swanger, her hair now al completely white. Some token presents. Pangle is picking a banjo, his grin infectious, and a third player, GEORGIA with a harmonica. As they play:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of Sally) She don't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't speak. I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at Sally) Is she feeble then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (to Sally) Don't mind him. (to Ruby) Hey Ruby: what about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts the tune of Wayfaring Stranger. Ruby groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make that face -- you listen:  c'mon Georgia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he starts up again, but this time GEORGIA BEGINS TO S He's like a pale angel and sings with a soft, true voice. Ruby finds herself taken by this boy's voice and by Stobr extraordinary invention as he takes the tune off on a wil journey. Ruby sits next to Ada, fiddles with her bracelet slips one from Ada's wrist and slides it over her own.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. EVENING
dialogues.text: They're all outside now, shaking hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's snow in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sleep here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bitter, they could stop one  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop one night, they'll want to  stop two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This coat's warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about next Sunday? That'll be  the New Year. It's gonna be a better  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war's over in a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said that a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking Stobrod's  hand in goodnight) It started off being over in a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Ada. Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. Pangle. Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three women walk down the lane, the three men watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my Ruby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's an original.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think the Good Lord would forgive  an old cold fool if he changed his  mind? Ada said it herself it was  bitter...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWANGER FARM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The three women head towards Sally's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of name's Georgia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's where he comes from, it's not  his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's meant to be the ugliest  state under the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you care what his name is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a funny look, then) What's that cluster of Stars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about them shaped like a  wishbone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Taurus the bull, and that's  Gemini and that's Orion's big dog,  Canis Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to her, Sal. She's turned  into a highland girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could always name the stars, Ruby,  that was never my problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all three have linked arms. Ada imitates Stobrod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you darling. In case that big  old sky falls on our heads. And I  love you, too. Sal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sad, Sal. It's a c-a-t-a-s-t-r- o-p-h-e.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ADA'S BEDROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. MORNING
dialogues.text: Ada at the window as, outside, SNOW FLAKES BEGIN TO FALL.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. MORNING
dialogues.text: Stobrod opens the door of the Mill. The SNOW FLAKES dissu him from venturing further. He goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sense setting off in snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, dressed, agitated -- the baby already complaining - is urgently shaking Inman. Hissing at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here, quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman surfaces from deep sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Federals are coming. They find you  here it'll go bad on all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is up, grabbing clothes, boots, his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can try and fight them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my baby. Please no! Just get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls up the window in back of the cabin. Inman throw things out into the freezing morning. He has his pants on but is otherwise naked. He swings over the window and dow onto the frosty ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman picks up his stuff and, at a crouch, runs for cover the wood which borders the property. He can hear horses a a commotion at the front of Sara's cabin, but doesn't loo round until he's sheltered by the trees. FEDERAL SOLDIERS, a raiding party, have dismounted and ar already wrangling with Sara. Inman watches, pulling on hi shirt, shivering, then his boots. Sara is standing in front of the hogpen, as if to protect the animal, but one of the soldiers, PISTOL, barges her t one side, toppling her, and opens the gate, starts herdin the hog out into the yard. A second soldier, NYM, emerges from the cabin, carrying Ethan. Sara starts up, struggles with him, is again knocked down.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GROUND IN THE MIDDLE OF THE YARD.
dialogues.text: Then Sara starts to scream. Inman is dressed. Boots on. He looks back at the yard. Th men sitting, smoking, prepared to wait, their breath comi out in gusts in the freezing air. Flakes of snow fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My baby's sick! Cover him up! He's  shaking! Have some pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third Federal, BARDOLPH, chases after the chickens, gat them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got nothing. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nym gets close to her, putting his rifle to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't necessarily so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Take me inside! Let's all go  inside! Take my baby inside and then  we'll do whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nym unties her. Pistol has a rope around the hog and now  leads it towards the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) There's nothing! You take that hog  I'm as good as dead. Cover up my  boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's wailing, an unbearable ululation. NYM SLAPS HER, TW HARD.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SARA'S CABIN. DAY
dialogues.text: The door is kicked open. Nym pushes Sara inside, kicks th door shut, REVEALING INMAN STANDING BEHIND IT.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SARA'S CABIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Bardolph, a chicken in his arms, goes over to the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ready to get a fit going.  It's shuddering. It's gone blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nym) How long does he want? Hey! Leave  some for the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pistol heads towards the cabin. As he approaches the door Bardolph rearranges the blankets to, cover the baby. Pist opens the door. Nym is on top of Sara. Pistol laughs, ent and is clubbed down by Inman, who steps out onto the porc while SARA SHRUGS OFF THE BODY OF NYM, HIS THROAT CUT. Bardolph looks up to see Inman walking towards him. Bardo has left his weapon by the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move away from the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bardolph obeys, terrified. Sara runs out, collects Ethan, gives a little moan of anguish, runs back inside the cabi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off your boots. (Bardolph does so) Take off your pants, and your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shoot me, please. We're  starving. We haven't eaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better get running before you  catch your death of cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, terrified) Thanks, thank you. I will.

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN A SHOT RINGS OUT AND HE CRASHES TO THE GROUND, D
dialogues.text: Behind Inman, Sara stands with a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: BOWL.
dialogues.text: There's a sense of ritual and order: the chapters of  transforming the hog into food. Sara is inside the cabin, the door open onto the yard. Sh holds the baby by the fireplace, swaddled up tight. She tries to put him to her breast, but he won't feed. Sh puts Ethan back in his crib, comes outside. Now Inman is butchering the hog, chopping down either sid of the spine to make two sides of meat. Now Sara is holdi up a sheet of hog fat, as if it were a lace shawl. Now sh rendering the fat into lard. Now Inman's salting the two  hams. Now Sara's washing the intestine. She sings all the while -- I dreamed that my bower was full of red swine an my bride bed full of blood -- they don't really converse. Inman continues to work. Sara goes back inside to Ethan's crib. Inman glances back but can hardly bear to, her anxiety so palpable. THE BABY DEAD. She looks at it. She takes it up in her arms. Kisse its forehead. Makes a strange stifling noise. Inman doesn't look at her She comes out again, shovels some of the food into a plat serves it up to Inman, gently touching him as she does so Then serves out food for herself. Inman starts to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
