dialogues.text: Inman nods. She collects up the knapsacks, including Inma and goes back inside the house with them. Inman squats,  eating, glancing back towards the cabin. There's the sudd shocking report of a revolver. Inman, knowing what it is, goes slowly towards the house its two dead bodies. His own face is a rictus, the eyes t slits. If he gave into his grief it would never cease.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SARA'S CABIN. DUSK
dialogues.text: From the house, the silhouette of Inman working outside i the day's dying light, snow falling around him. He's digg a grave. Inside the house, TWO BUNDLES, the small body wrapped in blanket, the other wrapped in the bed's patchwork quilt.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CABBAGE PATCH, BLACK COVE FARM. DUSK
dialogues.text: Still snowing. Ruby trudges past Ada who is digging out a couple of heads of the buried cabbages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) This snow. Isn't it supposed to fall  with bad news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad news is girls get working. I'm  going to round up the animals. (squints up at the  snow) This'll settle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks past. Ada stares into the distance where

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the snow falls down on Inman. He's hardly visible in i gusting waves. Just a thin black question mark, hunched o the elements, moving slowly forwards...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OLD MILL, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: THE SNOW HAS STOPPED. It's left a carpet on the ground. Stobrod, Pangle and Georgia emerge from the Old Mill. THE MAKE HEAVY FOOTPRINTS as they set off up the hill towards the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PATH IN THE MOUNTAINS. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman comes sliding down a crumbling slate hill and onto path. He cornea to a place where the path suddenly drops  away to reveal a view of the geography. And there, finall in the distance, Inman can see the blue ridge. Somewhere there is home, is Ada. He goes on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SLOPES OF COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Pangle walks too close to Stobrod and steps on the back o his boot which promptly detaches itself from Stobrod's fo Stobrod turns -- and with a raised finger -- pushes Pangl PANGLE FALLS IN THE SNOW, ARMS SPREADEAGLED, AND SMILES.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PIGEON RIVER BEHIND THE OLD MILL. DAY
dialogues.text: SOME HORSES CLUSTER around the Stobrod party's footprints Bosie swings acrobatically over his horse, to hang over t tracks, then up again into his saddle, looks at Teague. T Home Guard plod slowly forward in the direction of the tr

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. EVENING
dialogues.text: A CLEARING, fringed by poplars. Stobrod is making a fire. Pangle appears with an armful of firewood, his big grin a fixture. Then Georgia appears. He's carrying A SMALL BUCK frozen and covered with snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you reckon? Think we could  eat this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cook something long enough you  can eat anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prodding it) It's frozen. How long it been there  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very long.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SLOPES OF COLD MOUNTAIN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Teague examines the snow's imprinted silhouette of Pangle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgia joins in the chorus. Stobrod pulls one of the hic stick skewers out of the fire, blows on the, meat, smells smells again, looks at Georgia, takes a bite. Chews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pangle takes another stick, burns his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a bite from  his skewer) Don't taste much like venison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good. I think it's good.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND. COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The three men are asleep. The fire still burning. They're lying like petals of a flower around it. Suddenly Georgia sits bolt upright, grimaces, gets up stumbles away from t fire, toward a stand of trees, from which come the vivid  sounds of violent nausea.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREES NEAR THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: GEORGIA IS KNEELING IN THE SNOW, his head in the snow, wh he A HALF DOZEN RIDERS TROT PAST approaching the sleeping Stobrod and Pangle. Georgia has to vomit again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Teague rides up to the fire, the other riders with him -- Mo, Jo, Bosie, Grayling. Stobrod wakes, sits up, Pangle  sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening. Hope we didn't disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Teague. Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thewes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teague slides off his horse, approaches the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a deserter? -- don't mind if I  just warm up at your fire. (of the sleeping Pangle) That your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? That's a he!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're musicians. He picks the banjo,  I got a fiddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) Look pretty romantic by the fire.  Don't they? (to Stobrod) Your boyfriend's got a nice bit of  flesh on him. Close your eyes slip  inside that shirt get two good  handfuls -- dark enough I'd be  willing. I'm just kidding. (to his men) Tell him, I'm just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREES NEAR KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Georgia squints through the trees. Doesn't know what to d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you answer my question -- about  your military status?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Discharged. Took a wound at  Petersburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so like a hero's discharge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The military wouldn't take him. He  can't fight. He's simple. He's got a  mind no bigger'n a pickled walnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- he's fat, he's simple  and got titties -- but you're  insisting he ain't a woman. God damn!  Don't that sausage smell outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's very nervous) Miqhty outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mighty outstanding! There's a new  phrase. Mighty outstanding. Listen,  don't tell me -- you left your papers  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hero's discharge. For mighty  outstanding valour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're, they're, they're at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying himself) And where, where, where is your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're up the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunting. Drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On honeymoon. (to his men) I'm pretty fucking funny tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he going to play? (to Stobrod) You gonna play that fiddle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure. (kicks Pangle) Hey, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pangle surfaces, blinks, grins at everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Mrs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Where's Georgia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested) Where's Georgia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the trees, Georgia ducks, retches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't know what he's saying. We  were talking about Georgia early on --  maybe heading down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgia's like my armpit. Worse,  it's like yours. (to Pangle) Want some sausage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. You is Home Guard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You is Teague?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) I'm known!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't know what he's saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting) That bastard Teague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad words. Folk always put the curse  words in front of your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Teague wants us to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard there were deserters in  these parts. Hiding out in a big  cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not come to my ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know where this cave is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do, Stobes! He means --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right! he means, there is a  cave, right, it's up over the other  side, big cave, we played some music  up there, never occurred to me they  were deserters. Near Bearpen Branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nowhere near Bearpen Branch!  It's this side! He's always getting  lost. That cave -- we live there! --  it's over on Big Stomp. Tell you how  I always find it. There's a big old  locust tree fell down across the  path, that points straight at it,  like a finger, always a dozen  squirrels round that tree. You gets  to the tree, sit on it, and there's  your entrance, straight in front of  you, tree points at it. Come right  to your hand, them squirrels -- (makes a chirping  sound) -- Chrrrpppp! Chrrrrppp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good. Okay, let's eat, let's  hear some music.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREES NEAR KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Georgia watches as the music starts, Stobrod playing and  singing, Pangle joining in at the chorus. Their improvisi is wild, profound, Stobrod chording the fiddle, Pangle  following him, then, finishing with another verse and end with the title declaimed by Stobrod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call this tune: Ruby's Lament.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Something like compassion has flickered over Teague's fac Mo and Jo nod to the music's secret rhythms. Only Bosie s detached, contemplating his long fingernail. The music  finishes. The Home Guard applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you make of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heartbreaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand over by that tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over by that tree. Over there. Take  your boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stobrod gets up, carrying his fiddle, heads over to a big old poplar. Nods at Pangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pangle gets up, banjo in his hand. Puts his arm around St as if they were about to be photographed. The Home Guard  gather around them. From the trees Georgia watches, helpl Pangle grins at Teague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always smiles. He don't mean  nothing by it. I told him this world's  got nothing worth a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your hat over your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cover your face with your hat.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREES NEAR THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Georgia lies prostrate in the snow, shuddering under the  report of each bullet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOTTOM FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby working in the snow, in the field, clipping a sheep' feet, the animal on its back between Ruby's knees. She lo up to see GEORGIA RUNNING ACROSS THE FIELD TOWARDS HER,  calling out her name. From the kitchen window, Ada looks as he reaches Ruby, the story pouring from him. Ada emerg from the house, walks towards the bad news.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STOREROOM, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby sorting out a kit of shovels, blankets. Ada comes in doesn't know how to help her friend, who shows no emotion

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told Georgia he can stop here,  sleep in the barn. He's got nothing  inside him. He'd walk out of here  and die in the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can milk the cows. I was worrying  about that. It'll be dark in a couple  of hours. I's ten hours climb from  here. He's drawn a map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boiling) You know these fools stayed the night  in the Mill? That's Stobrod -- he  can't do one good thing without adding  the bad. Left tracks in the snow all  the way up for them Home Guards to  follow. That's a sign says shoot me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada moves towards her, puts her arms around her. Ruby is  rigid. Ada stops embracing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's tying up the kit. She doesn't know how to grieve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every piece of this is a man's  bullshit. They call this a war a  cloud over the land, but they made  the weather. Then they stand in the  rain and say: shit! It's raining! (tears welling) If I cry one tear for my Daddy I  stole it off a crocodile.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNOW IS FALLING HEAVILY. RUBY AND ADA TRUDGE UP THE
dialogues.text: MOUNTAIN, dressed in Monroe's clothes, hats pulled down,  leading the horse, which is loaded up with tools and supp A choice of paths. They start up one, then Ruby decides  against it, consults the map, and they reverse, pulling t horse back and then yanking it up the other path.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PI STRUCTURE, COLD MOUNTAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ruby and Ada have made a fire. They sleep under a stone  structure, which forms a natural pi shape, the fire in th entrance, the snow caught in its light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. MORNING
dialogues.text: Ada and Ruby arrive at the scene of murder. Pangle is keeled over at the old Poplar, snow covering hi Only his girth and a glimpse of coat identify him. Ada brushes some of the snow from his face, revealing the death wound, then lays a hand in blessing on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Teague's took him. They did  that with the Swanger boys -- didn't,  they? -- dragged them into town,  then strung them up as warning...  it's snowed since, so I can't read  the story on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada fishes out Pangle's banjo from the snow. It's broken the strings hang slack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER -- and RUBY FINISHES OFF THE GRAVE, hammering in a  stone to mark the place. Ada walks away towards the creek to wash her hands. She bends and rinses her face. As she looks up SHE SEES STOBROD ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE CREEK; half-in, half out of the water, slumped against a  tree, blood everywhere, staining the crust of snow which  covers him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby! Ruby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby arrives at Ada, looks to where she's looking, walks  straight into the creek, all her love contained in the ur with which she hurtles to her father, oblivious to the  freezing water. She puts a head to his chest, seeks out a pulse at his wrist. Calls back to Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still breathing! (to Stobrod) God damn! Daddy; Daddy -- it's Ruby.  Don't you die on me again. (to Ada) He's still breathing!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A mean fire burns by the creek. RUBY TURNS A KNIFE IN THE FLAMES. Stobrod's back is exposed. Just by the shoulder b is an ugly grey and purple bulge the size of a crabapple. Ruby turns to Ada, who is helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pack a pan full of snow. I need good  clean water, boiled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuts the skin and prises out a slug which she drops i the snow and rolls around to clean. Stobrod doesn't move. could be dead. Ada loads the pan with snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get him home. We have herbs  there and it's warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll die first. He's got hardly no  blood left in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll die lying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a place further on up. Used  to be. Old Cherokee place. There's  good water right by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada puts the snow-packed pan on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BY THE OUTLIER'S CAVE, COLD MOUNTAIN. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Squirrels frolic. Teague sits on the trunk of a fallen tr He feeds the squirrels, looking straight ahead where the  mouth of a cave winks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO WOMEN EMERGE FROM A STEEP TUNNEL OF TREES IN A
dialogues.text: CHESTNUT GROVE. There's a stream and, up on the bank, A  CLUSTER OF BLACK CONICAL HUTS, made up of chestnut logs,  abandoned and slightly sinister looking. They approach on of the huts, its door long lost. The snow has drifted in. second hut has a door which they pry open. It's dark and  cold, but apparently still weatherproof. They get Stobrod off the horse and carry him inside, then come out again t unload the horse of its remaining load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This horse is weary. He's ready to  give up the ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby picks up the blankets and provisions and goes back i to her father. Ada takes the horse to another hut and, de his great reluctance, pushes him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy. (she blows into his  nostrils, calming  him) That's warmer, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada wouldn't even recognize this practical, hardy woman s become. Stringy and of few words. She sets off towards th tree tunnel, passing Stobrod's hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting firewood.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE KILLING GROUND, COLD MOUNTAIN. DUSK
dialogues.text: Inman approaches the Killing Ground. He studies the groun finds Pangle's grave. Blood has left its black writing in the snow and he finds first where Stobrod has been, where the bullet had been removed, then the journey away, still tiny, telltale spatters of blood, and the hoof prints and boot prints of two walkers and one loaded horse. He puts hand into the ashes of Ruby's fire, can't feel any warmth It's getting dark. He takes a drink from the stream, shud at the cold.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STOBROD'S HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The fire burns, a pall of smoke. Stobrod lies on the grou swathed in blankets. Coughs. Ruby sits next to him, wipes the hair from his forehead. Ada opens her eyes, looks, cl them, listens to the fire, a strange squeaking as it burn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wood -- that sound when it burns  that mean more snow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it do, country girl.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRACK, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAWN
dialogues.text: First light. The sun creeps up, a red streak of dawn. Inm walking, his head bent to the tracks. He walks quickly, e as the terrain gets more steep. As he bends to the snow - where a spot of blood has fallen into a hoof print -- A F OF SNOW LANDS ON HIS HAND. Then a second. He looks up. Th snow falls. He starts to move more quickly, racing the snow as it see to erase the tracks. The snow thickens.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREE TUNNEL NEAR CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING
dialogues.text: In the Chestnut Grovel A DOZEN WILD TURKEYS pick their wa across the snow. A shotgun lines up its sight at one of t The trigger is squeezed. An explosion of feathers.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THREE WAY CROSSING, COLD MOUNTAIN. MORNING
dialogues.text: Inman hears the shot. Then a second, the sound ricochetin around him. He can't quite identify its source but he run again, heading for the Chestnut trees he can see above hi

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREE TUNNEL NEAR CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING
dialogues.text: Ada collects the two turkeys, the first creatures she's e shot. Doesn't quite know how to hold them. She straighten up and sees, at the other end of the tree tunnel, backlit the morning sun, THE SILHOUETTE OF A MAN. She drops the  turkeys tires to reload the shotgun. Inman comes down the tunnel, approaching the hunter he se through the snow at the other end of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn round and go back where you  came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman is bewildered by this woman's voice in a man's outf keeps walking, peering through the snow. Ada fires a warn shot. Inman, still some distance, suddenly understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada? Ada Monroe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all this time, all this way, Inman could give up th ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I believe I made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, walks heavily away from her. Then he turns agai completely lost, without compass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I knew where to go I'd go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally recognising  him) Inman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. They don't know how to speak to each other, just stand awkwardly, some distance apart, the emotion stones their throats. Eventually --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, she starts to sob, and sob. VERY HIGH ANGLE: Inman walks towards Ada. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STOBROD'S HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING
dialogues.text: Ada enters, Inman behind her. Ruby looks up from Stobrod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby, this is Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby digests this. Considers this ghost of a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, I should send you  out with a shotgun more often. He  looks as he needs sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may need to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be my guest. You shot or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry? (Inman nods, Ruby to  Ada) He woke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stobrod?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said -- your mommy's name was Grace  then closed his eyes again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHEROKEE VILLAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada comes out of Stobrod's hut, a glimpse of Inman sleepi on the floor, heads for another hut which Ruby is sweepin out. The snow has stopped. Ada stands in the door, watche Ruby. Ruby's resistance to Inman is palpable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep. They both are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised. Your man looks  played out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him. I realize now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw him when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Sally Swanger's well. A tunnel of  trees. The man like a black smudge  in the snow, the sun behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing is it wasn't the same.  The image. It wasn't snowing. And in  the well, he was, as if he were  falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably don't remember it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember it exactly. There were  crows, these black crows flying  towards me. I thought I was seeing  him fall. Instead I was seeing him  come back to me. All this while I've  been packing ice around my heart.  How will I make it melt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get a fire going. (goes to the fireplace) I've got big plans for that farm.  Got a vision in my mind of how that  Cove needs to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not a thing we can't do  ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ADA AND RUBY HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: THE FIRE BURNS. Ada lies awake. Ruby sleeping. Ada gets u steps out into the snow, her blanket around her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ADA AND RUBY HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Inman is outside his cabin. Only the light escaping from cabin, fire lights them, almost silhouettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was trying to be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I got no appetite left to be in a  room with wounded men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a face you recognised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get my letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got three letters. Carried them in  that book you gave me. The Bertram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have sent 100. Did you write  to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever I could. If you never got  them I can summarize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray you're well. I pray I'm in  your thoughts. You are all that keeps  me from sliding into some dark place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how did I keep you? We barely  knew each other. A few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand moments. They're like a  bag of tiny diamonds glittering in a  black heart. Don't matter if they're  real or things I made up. The shape  of your neck. The way you felt under  my hands when I pulled you to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boots, one polished, one not  yet polished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're playing a piano and I'm  standing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm playing a piano and you're  standing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kiss -- which I've kissed again  every day of my walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day of my waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can't see my face, but if  you could see my inside, my whatever  you want to name it, my spirit, that's  the fear I have deeper than any gash  on my neck. I think I'm ruined. They  kept trying to put me in the ground,  but I wasn't ready, no ma'am, no  more ready than that scoundrel in  there's not ready to die on us. But  if I had goodness, I lost it. If I  had anything tender in me I shot it  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby stomps out of the hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one -- shut this door, it's  freezing. (goes over to Stobrod's  hut) Number two -- shut that door, it's  freezing. (turns to them) I'm laying on my back, with my fingers  poked in my ears trying to shut out  who's got a bag of diamonds and who's  got boots needs polishing, If you  want to get three feet up a bull's  ass listen to what sweethearts whisper  to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at the door to Stobrod's hut. She contemplates them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, if you're going to wimble  all night I'm going to sleep in with  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that she enters Stobrod's hut, slamming the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I can't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Ruby's vacating my hut  so that you can sleep in a different  one.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ADA AND RUBY HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ada puts logs onto the fire. After a few moments a knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman enters. They don't know the rules for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever comes to pass between you  and me, I want Ruby to stay in Black  Cove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as she wants. And if she  never leaves I'll be glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More a question could she put up  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you understand she's my friend,  she's not a hired hand and she doesn't  empty a night jar unless it's her  own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This war's made some things pointless.  It's hard to imagine a wedding. I  think even my father would recognize  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada, I want to marry you. If you'll  have me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there's some religion where  you just have to say I marry you,  three times, and then you're man and  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I marry you. I marry you. I marry  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada laughs, unsettling Inman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think it's I divorce you three  times and then you're not married  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You waited enough. I certainly did.  I marry you. I marry you. I marry  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they kiss, tentative, then more urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about the way I look. In  these clothes. (Inman shakes his  head) And there are so many buttons. (starts to undress) Will you turn your back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for all the gold dollars in the  Federal Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands holding her clothes in front of her to cover  herself. He takes them from her, drops them to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING
dialogues.text: A crisp, cold beautiful morning. They're packing up, all  their clothes in layers. Inman prepares the horse. Ruby a Ada carrying bundles out of the huts. Inman approaches Ru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go ahead. I'll follow with the  horse at a pace your daddy can  tolerate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can all go together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's safer this way. No one has  quarrel with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruby) I gather I need permission if I reckon  on living at Black Cove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby gives a curt nod, goes over to Stobrod's hut. Inman  gets close to Ada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get to you by nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand to his mouth which creases into a smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Mr. Bartram speaks about some  category of fly born on the hide of  a cow. It flies up into a tree and  waits and waits until it smells cow.  It can wait a year, two years, I  don't know, maybe longer. Then a cow  comes along and it wakes up, flies  down, lays its eggs on the cow.  There's purpose for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And am I the fly in this story, or  the cow?

dialogues.speaker: INT. STOBROD'S HUT, CHEROKEE VILLAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby is wrapping a fragile Stobrod for the journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come up the mountain for me,  darling, I'd be dead otherwise, dead  and gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have found some other fool to  rescue you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sweet on you, that Georgia boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He coughs for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say a thing and then cough  it's a lie. Daddy, stay on that horse,  and don't lose him or sell him. We'll  need him on the farm.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHEROKEE VILLAGE. MORNING
dialogues.text: And then the two women are off, little men in their outfi tramping off in the snow. Inman watches.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRACK NEAR THREE WAY CROSSING, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ruby and Ada walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that Georgia boy's been seeing  to the animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were thinking on him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not. I was thinking on swollen  udders -- and before you say same  difference...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby elbows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss lovey-dovey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ada elbows her back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THREE WAY CROSSING, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman has roped Stobrod to the horse which he pulls down steep slope. Behind him, their hooves muffled by the snow

dialogues.speaker: GROUP OF RIDERS JOIN THE TRAIL, IN SLOW BUT STEADY PURSUI
dialogues.text: Inman walks on, apparently oblivious to who's behind him. and Stobrod are some distance from broken ground, a fring of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Stobrod) Don't look round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many men does he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were five. You can't reason  with that man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes off his gloves) I got a conversation stopper. (they're getting closer) Closer we get to that broken ground  the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inman opens his coat. Stobrod looks at the Lemats. They'r at the edge of the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hold on tight, do you hear? When  I say three, look round, nice and  slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stobrod looks round. Inman doesn't. Teague has some new b in his entourage but they're all dead. A SPARE HORSE HAS

dialogues.speaker: LITTER WITH A COUPLE MORE, SOUVENIRS OF THEIR CAVE VISIT.
dialogues.text: Teague waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn! You're a hard fucker to  put down. (they approach) Good directions to that cave from  the fat boy -- saw the squirrels,  sat on the tree made some friends,  brought some back with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His riders begin, quite casually, to fan out.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT KNOCKS JO FROM HIS HORSE, THE SECOND MO, WHO FALLS I
dialogues.text: THE SNOW, BLEEDING FROM THE GROIN AND SCREAMING. The ride horse gets tangled up with the others. Inman is in the trees, shots around him. He doesn't move  away from, but towards the riders inside the line of tree Grayling charges him, riding into the trees. INMAN SHOOTS

dialogues.speaker: RIDES AWAY, EVIDENTLY NOT RELISHING THE FIGHT, AND THROWS
dialogues.text: HIMSELF AT TEAGUE, WHOSE HORSE IS BUCKING WILDLY. Teague' carbine fires an involuntary shot into the air. Inman yan the gun from his hand with his own left hand and lets go shotgun barrel of the Lemats with the other, the big pist almost leaping from his hand with the recoil. TEAGUE'S CH OPENS OUT AS HE'S THROWN OFF THE HORSE. Mo is still screa Inman walks over and shoots him in the head, then walks t Teague, who is saying something, the blood blotting the s under him. Inman studies him, picks up the Spencer carbine, turns to look where Bosie has gone, steps up onto Teague's horse,  reins the horse in, and trots it over to the prostrate Te LEANS OVER AND SHOOTS HIM DEAD. He turns the horse in the direction Bosie had headed. He can't see horse or rider, in the stand of Hickory Trees ahead, THE GUSTS OF STEAMIN BREATH betray them both. He rides slowly towards the stan of trees.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada and Ruby walking. They hear the shots. Ada turns and  starts to run through the snow, her hat flying from her h

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STAND OF HICKORY TREES, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Inman's horse is parallel to Bosie, who is deep inside th trees but also riding, slowly. It's like a dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. Here's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to shoot the horse from  under you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot her. She's not mine. You riding  Mr Teague's mare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. (wearily, as he brings  his horse inside the  trees) Look, how old are you? Give me your  gun and ride home, I'm done fighting.  I'm sick of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give you my gun you'll shoot me  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not shoot you, but nor am I  walking down that mountain looking  over my shoulder for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they call a conundrum. I  tell you what I've got on my side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got on your side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The confidence of youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in that second HE PRODUCES HIS GUN AND FIRES. INMAN H

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIDGE, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada and Ruby running. THEY REACH STOBROD, HIS HORSE STOPP DRINKING FROM THE CREEK. Stobrod, barely conscious, hangi halfway down its flank, held on by the ropes. Ada hurries on, taking the shotgun from Ruby, who tends t her father.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A GROVE OF TREES, COLD MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ada runs past the horse dragging the cave corpses. She ha stops to look at the bodies, just rushes on. THE GROUND SIMPLIFIES AND SHE'S AT THE BOTTOM OF A GROVE.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNOW.
dialogues.text: She runs, her heart broken, towards the body of Inman. He dead, the red flag of his life ebbed, away in the snow. A falls to her knees and pulls him over, the snow crusted o his face, which she wipes away with great tenderness, the sits, his head in her lap, as Ruby slowly comes up the hi towards them. A VIOLIN PLAYS, quite raucous.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, BLACK COVE FARM, EASTER. DAY
dialogues.text: A GIRL, about five or six, with Ada's curls, sits at the  table cradling a tiny lamb, which won't feed from the nip bottle she offers it. She tries again. Ada comes in sudde takes a knife from the kitchen, and hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bring that lamb outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl gets up, carries the lamb out into the field.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELD, BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: THE SOUND OF THE FIDDLE CONTINUING, JOINED BY A BANJO, It a glorious spring morning, Black Cove Farm at its most  luxuriant, the path edged with brilliant flowers. There a more animals in evidence. The girl emerges from the house and sees Ada in the field, surrounded by sheep. She hurri over. ADA IS EXPERTLY SKINNING A STILLBORN LAMB. The little gir is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came out dead, love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has the skin off the lamb, which lies like a little p cat on the ground. She approaches Grace, takes the live l from her arms, the girl resistant, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to kill him. But we  have to try something or else he's  going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the skin and wraps it round Grace's lamb. Then  puts the covered lamb into the pen with the dead lamb's  mother. It goes to the sheep and, after a few false starts, start to feed, accepted as a surrogate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a small mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And A VOICE joins in with the fiddle and banjo.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLACK COVE FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: STOBROD is playing, on his repaired fiddle. His hair is n completely grey. GEORGIA is playing the banjo and singing although. A SMALL CHILD with Georgia's reddish coloring k invading his picking hand trying to join in. RUBY HAS ANO GEORGIA CHILD IN HER ARMS, but is also trying to serve fo She passes Georgia and touches the top of his head. SALLY SWANGER is pouring water from a jug, Ada emerges from the kitchen, with a big pie, racing to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Hot hot hot hot hot!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind her, Grace appears, carrying a jug of milk, p it on the groaning board of the table. Grace has a full p in front of her, picks up a fork to spear some meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace Inman, nobody said eat. (then to Stobrod) Mr. Thewes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music stops. And there's quiet except for the sound o animals: lowing, barking, braying, bleating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For good friends, good food, good  family: for all our blessings -- Oh  Lord we thank thee. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they eat.
